This proves the existence of elements KK as claimed.

It is clear that conjugation induces an algebra homomorphism, and since the map is a linear isomorphism on the space of generators, it is an algebra isomorphism on the algebras being generated (12).

(While the elements KK in (11) are far from being unique themselves, equation (11) says that the map on generators induced by conjugation with KK is independent of this choice.)

Proposition

(system of generating algebras is causally local net)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, let ùíÆ\mathcal{S} be a corresponding S-matrix scheme according to def. 3, and let

L int‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g]] \mathbf{L}_{int} \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar , g ] ]

be a Lagrangian density, to be thought of as an interaction.

Then the system

Gen(E BV-BRST,L int):CausCldSubsets(Œ£)‚ü∂Algebra Gen(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int}) \;\colon\; CausCldSubsets(\Sigma) \longrightarrow Algebra

of localized generating functions for interacting field observables (def. 8) is a causally local net in that it satisfies the following conditions:

  1. (isotony) For every inclusion ùí™ 1‚äÇùí™ 2\mathcal{O}_1 \subset \mathcal{O}_2 of causally closed subsets of spacetime the corresponding algebra homomorphism is a monomorphism

    i ùí™ 1,ùí™ 2:Gen(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™ 1)‚Ü™Gen(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™ 2) i_{\mathcal{O}_1, \mathcal{O}_2} \;\colon\; Gen(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}_1) \hookrightarrow Gen(E_{\text{BV-BRST}},\mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}_2)

  2. (causal locality) For ùí™ 1,ùí™ 2‚äÇX\mathcal{O}_1, \mathcal{O}_2 \subset X two causally closed subsets which are spacelike separated, in that their causal ordering (def. \ref{CausalOrdering}) satisfies

    ùí™ 1‚à®‚àßùí™ 2andùí™ 2‚à®‚àßùí™ 1 \mathcal{O}_1 {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \mathcal{O}_2 \;\text{and}\; \mathcal{O}_2 {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \mathcal{O}_1

    and for ùí™‚äÇŒ£\mathcal{O} \subset \Sigma any further causally closed subset which contains both

    ùí™ 1,ùí™ 2‚äÇùí™ \mathcal{O}_1 , \mathcal{O}_2 \subset \mathcal{O}

    then the corresponding images of the generating function algebras of interacting field observables localized in ùí™ 1\mathcal{O}_1 and in ùí™ 2\mathcal{O}_2, respectively, commute with each other as subalgebras of the generating function algebras of interacting field observables localized in ùí™\mathcal{O}:

    [i ùí™ 1,ùí™(Gen L int(ùí™ 1)),i ùí™ 2,ùí™(Gen L int(ùí™ 2))]=0‚ààGen(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™). \left[ i_{\mathcal{O}_1,\mathcal{O}}(Gen_{L_{int}}(\mathcal{O}_1)) \;,\; i_{\mathcal{O}_2,\mathcal{O}}(Gen_{L_{int}}(\mathcal{O}_2)) \right] \;=\; 0 \;\;\; \in Gen(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}) \,.

(D√ºtsch-Fredenhagen 00, section 3, following Brunetti-Fredenhagen 99, section 8, Il‚Äôin-Slavnov 78)

Proof

Isotony is immediate from the definition of the algebra homomorphisms in def. 8.

By the isomorphism (12) we may check causal localizy with respect to any choice of adiabatic switching g sw‚ààCautoff(ùí™)g_{sw} \in Cautoff(\mathcal{O}) constant over ùí™\mathcal{O}. For this the statement follows, with the assumption of spacelike separation, by causal additivity (prop. 1):

For supp(A 1)‚äÇùí™ 1supp(A_1) \subset \mathcal{O}_1 and supp(A 2)‚äÇùí™ 2supp(A_2) \subset \mathcal{O}_2 we have:

ùíµ gS int,sw(jA 1)ùíµ gS int,sw(jA 2) =ùíÆ gS int,sw(jA 1+jA 2) =ùíÆ gS int,sw(jA 2+jA 1) =ùíµ gS int,sw(jA 2)ùíµ gS int,sw(jA 1) \begin{aligned} \mathcal{Z}_{g S_{int,sw}}( j A_1 ) \mathcal{Z}_{g S_{int,sw}}( j A_2 ) & = \mathcal{S}_{g S_{int,sw}}( j A_1 + j A_2) \\ & = \mathcal{S}_{g S_{int,sw}}( j A_2 + j A_1) \\ & = \mathcal{Z}_{g S_{int,sw}}( j A_2 ) \mathcal{Z}_{g S_{int,sw}}( j A_1 ) \end{aligned}

With the causally local net of localized generating functions for interacting field observables in hand, it is now immediate to get the

Definition

(system of interacting field algebras of observables)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, let ùíÆ\mathcal{S} be a corresponding S-matrix scheme according to def. 3, and let

L int‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g]] \mathbf{L}_{int} \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar , g ] ]

be a Lagrangian density, to be thought of as an interaction, so that for g sw‚ààC sp ‚àû(Œ£)‚ü®g‚ü©g_{sw} \in C^\infty_{sp}(\Sigma)\langle g \rangle an adiabatic switching the transgression

gS int,sw‚âîgœÑ Œ£(g swL int)‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g]]‚ü®g‚ü© g S_{int,sw} \;\coloneqq\; g \tau_\Sigma(g_{sw} \mathbf{L}_{int}) \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g ] ]\langle g \rangle

is a local observable, to be thought of as an adiabatically switched interaction action functional.

For ùí™‚äÇŒ£\mathcal{O} \subset \Sigma a causally closed subset of spacetime (def. \ref{CausalComplementOfSubsetOfLorentzianManifold}) and for g sw‚ààCutoffs(ùí™)g_{sw} \in Cutoffs(\mathcal{O}) an compatible adiabatic switching function (def. \ref{CutoffFunctions}) write

IntObs(E BV-BRST,S int,sw)(ùí™)‚âî‚ü®i‚Ñèddjùíµ S int(jA)| j=0|supp(A)‚äÇùí™‚ü©‚äÇPolyObs((‚Ñè))[[g]] IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, S_{int,sw})(\mathcal{O}) \coloneqq \left\langle i \hbar \frac{d}{d j} \mathcal{Z}_{S_{int}}(j A)\vert_{j = 0} \;\vert\; supp(A) \subset \mathcal{O} \right\rangle \;\subset\; PolyObs((\hbar))[ [ g ] ]

for the interacting field algebra of observables (def. 7) with spacetime support in ùí™\mathcal{O}.

Let then

IntObs(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™)‚äÇ‚àèg sw‚ààCutoffs(ùí™)IntObs(E BV-BRST,S int,sw)(ùí™) IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}) \subset \underset{g_{sw} \in Cutoffs(\mathcal{O})}{\prod} IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, S_{int,sw})(\mathcal{O})

be the subalgebra of the Cartesian product of all these algebras as g swg_{sw} ranges, which is generated by the tuples

i‚Ñèddjùíµ L int| j=0‚âî(i‚Ñèddjùíµ S int,sw(jA)| j=0) g sw‚ààCutoffs(ùí™) i \hbar \frac{d}{d j } \mathcal{Z}_{\mathbf{L}_{int}}\vert_{j = 0} \;\coloneqq\; \left( i \hbar \frac{d}{d j } \mathcal{Z}_{S_{int,sw}} (j A)\vert_{j = 0} \right)_{g_{sw} \in Cutoffs(\mathcal{O})}

for supp(A)‚äÇùí™supp(A) \subset \mathcal{O}.

Finally, for ùí™ 1‚äÇùí™ 2\mathcal{O}_1 \subset \mathcal{O}_2 an inclusion of two causally closed subsets, let

i ùí™ 1,ùí™ 2:IntObs(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™ 1)‚ü∂IntObs(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™ 2) i_{\mathcal{O}_1, \mathcal{O}_2} \;\colon\; IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}_1) \longrightarrow IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}_2)

be the algebra homomorphism which is given simply by restricting the index set of tuples.

This construction defines a functor

IntObs(E BV-BRST,L int):CausClsdSubsets(Œ£)‚ü∂Algebras IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int}) \;\colon\; CausClsdSubsets(\Sigma) \longrightarrow Algebras

from the poset of causally closed subsets in the spacetime Œ£\Sigma to the category of star algebras.

Finally, as a direct corollary of prop. 4, we obtain the key result:

Proposition

(system of interacting field algebras of observables is causally local)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, let ùíÆ\mathcal{S} be a corresponding S-matrix scheme according to def. 3, and let

L int‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g]]. \mathbf{L}_{int} \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar , g ] ] \,.

be a Lagrangian density, to be thought of as an interaction, then the system of algebras of observables Obs L intObs_{L_{int}} (def. 9) is a local net of observables in that

  1. (isotony) For every inclusion ùí™ 1‚äÇùí™ 2\mathcal{O}_1 \subset \mathcal{O}_2 of causally closed subsets the corresponding algebra homomorphism is a monomorphism

    i ùí™ 1,ùí™ 2:IntObs(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™ 1)‚Ü™IntObs(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™ 2) i_{\mathcal{O}_1, \mathcal{O}_2} \;\colon\; IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}_1) \hookrightarrow IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}_2)

  2. (causal locality) For ùí™ 1,ùí™ 2‚äÇX\mathcal{O}_1, \mathcal{O}_2 \subset X two causally closed subsets which are spacelike separated, in that their causal ordering (def. \ref{CausalOrdering}) satisfies

    ùí™ 1‚à®‚àßùí™ 2andùí™ 2‚à®‚àßùí™ 1 \mathcal{O}_1 {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \mathcal{O}_2 \;\text{and}\; \mathcal{O}_2 {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \mathcal{O}_1

    and for ùí™‚äÇŒ£\mathcal{O} \subset \Sigma any further causally closed subset which contains both

    ùí™ 1,ùí™ 2‚äÇùí™ \mathcal{O}_1 , \mathcal{O}_2 \subset \mathcal{O}

    then the corresponding images of the generating algebras of ùí™ 1\mathcal{O}_1 and ùí™ 2\mathcal{O}_2, respectively, commute with each other as subalgebras of the generating algebra of ùí™\mathcal{O}:

    [i ùí™ 1,ùí™(Obs L int(ùí™ 1)),i ùí™ 2,ùí™(Obs L int(ùí™ 2))]=0‚ààIntObs(E BV-BRST,L int)(ùí™). \left[ i_{\mathcal{O}_1,\mathcal{O}}(Obs_{\mathbf{L}_{int}}(\mathcal{O}_1)) \;,\; i_{\mathcal{O}_2,\mathcal{O}}(Obs_{\mathbf{L}_{int}}(\mathcal{O}_2)) \right] \;=\; 0 \;\;\; \in IntObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}_{int})(\mathcal{O}) \,.

(D√ºtsch-Fredenhagen 00, below (17), following Brunetti-Fredenhagen 99, section 8, Il‚Äôin-Slavnov 78)

Proof

The first point is again immediate from the definition (def. 9).

For the second point it is sufficient to check the commutativity relation on generators. For these the statement follows with prop. 4:

[i‚Ñèddjùíµ S int,sw(jA 1)| j=0,i‚Ñèddjùíµ S int,sw(jJ 2)| j=0] =(i‚Ñè) 2‚àÇ 2‚àÇj 1‚àÇj 2[ùíµ S int,sw(j 1A 1),ùíµ S int,sw(j 1A 2)]‚èü=0 |j 1=0j 2=0 =0 \begin{aligned} & \left[ i \hbar \frac{d}{d j} \mathcal{Z}_{S_{int,sw}}(j A_1)\vert_{j = 0} \;,\; i \hbar \frac{d}{d j} \mathcal{Z}_{S_{int,sw}}(j J_2)\vert_{j = 0} \right] \\ & = (i \hbar)^2 \frac{ \partial^2 }{ \partial j_1 \partial j_2 } \underset{ = 0}{ \underbrace{ \left[ \mathcal{Z}_{S_{int,sw}}(j_1 A_1) \;,\; \mathcal{Z}_{S_{int,sw}}(j_1 A_2) \right]}}_{ \left\vert { {j_1 = 0} \atop {j_2 = 0} } \right. } \\ & = 0 \end{aligned}

\,

Time-ordered products

Definition 3 suggests to focus on the multilinear operations T(...)T(...) which define the perturbative S-matrix order-by-order in ‚Ñè\hbar. We impose axioms on these time-ordered products directly (def. 10) and then prove that these axioms imply the axioms for the corresponding S-matrix (prop. 9 below).

Definition

(time-ordered product)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a free vacuum according to def. 1.

A time-ordered product is a sequence of multi-linear continuous functionals for all k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N} of the form

T k:(LocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]) ‚äó ‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]] k‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg((‚Ñè))[[g,j]] T_k \;\colon\; \left( {\, \atop \,} LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [\hbar, g, j] ] {\, \atop \,} \right)^{\otimes^k_{\mathbb{C}[ [\hbar, g, j] ]}} \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}((\hbar))[ [g , j] ]

(from tensor products of local observables to microcausal polynomial observables, with formal parameters adjoined according to def. 2) such that the following conditions hold for all possible arguments:

  1. (normalization)

    T 0(A)=1 T_0(A) = 1

  2. (perturbation)

    T 1(A)=:A: T_1(A) = :A:

  3. (symmetry) each T kT_k is graded-symmetric in its arguments, in that

    (A œÉ(1)‚ãÖA œÉ(2)‚ãØA œÉ(k‚àí1)‚ãÖA œÉ(k)=(‚àí) œµA 1‚ãÖA 2‚ãØA k‚àí1‚ãÖA k)‚áí(T k(A œÉ(1),‚Ä¶,A œÉ(k))=(‚àí) œµT k(A 1,‚Ä¶,A k)) \left( {\, \atop \,} A_{\sigma(1)} \cdot A_{\sigma(2)} \cdots A_{\sigma(k-1)} \cdot A_{\sigma(k)} = (-)^\epsilon A_1 \cdot A_2 \cdots A_{k-1} \cdot A_k {\, \atop \,} \right) \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \left( {\, \atop \,} T_k(A_{\sigma(1)}, \ldots, A_{\sigma(k)}) = (-)^\epsilon T_k(A_1, \ldots, A_k) {\, \atop \,} \right)

    for all tuples of local observables A 1,‚Ä¶,A k‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]A_1, \ldots, A_k \in LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [\hbar, g, j] ] and any permutation œÉ‚ààŒ£(k)\sigma\in \Sigma(k)

  4. (causal factorization) If

    (supp(A 1)‚à™‚ãØ‚à™supp(A r))‚à®‚àß(supp(A r+1)‚à™‚ãØ‚à™supp(A k)) \left( {\, \atop \,} supp(A_1) \cup \cdots \cup supp(A_r) {\, \atop \,} \right) \;{\vee\!\!\!\wedge}\; \left( {\, \atop \,} supp(A_{r+1}) \cup \cdots \cup supp(A_k) {\, \atop \,} \right)

    then

    T(A 1,‚ãØ,A k)=T(A 1,‚ãØ,A r)T(A r+1,‚ãØ,A k). T(A_1, \cdots, A_k) \; = \; T( A_1, \cdots , A_r ) \, T( A_{r+1}, \cdots , A_k ) \,.
Remark

(time-ordered products as generalized functions)

It is convenient (as in Epstein-Glaser 73) to think of time-ordered products (def. 10), being Wick algebra-valued distributions (hence operator-valued distributions if we were to choose a representation of the Wick algebra by linear operators on a Hilbert space), as generalized functions depending on spacetime points:

If

{Œ± ‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E BV-BRST)‚ü®g‚ü©}‚à™{Œ≤ j‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E BV-BRST)‚ü®j‚ü©} \left\{ \alpha_ \in \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})\langle g \rangle \right\} \cup \left\{ \beta_j \in \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})\langle j \rangle \right\}

is a finite set of horizontal differential forms, and

{g i,j j‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)} \left\{ g_i, j_{j} \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma) \right\}

is a corresponding set of bump functions on spacetime (adiabatic switchings), so that

{S j:Œ¶‚Ü¶‚à´Œ£g i(x)(j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *Œ± i)(x)dvol Œ£(x)}‚à™{A j:Œ¶‚Ü¶‚à´Œ£j i(x)(j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *Œ≤ i)(x)dvol Œ£(x)} \left\{ S_j \colon \Phi \mapsto \underset{\Sigma}{\int} g_i(x) \, \left(j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \alpha_i\right)(x)\, dvol_\Sigma(x) \right\} \;\cup\; \left\{ A_j \colon \Phi \mapsto \underset{\Sigma}{\int} j_i(x) \, \left(j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \beta_i\right)(x)\, dvol_\Sigma(x) \right\}

is the corresponding set of local observables, then we may write the time-ordered product of these observables as the integration of these bump functions against a generalized function T (Œ± i)T_{(\alpha_i)} with values in the Wick algebra:

‚à´Œ£ nT (Œ± i),(Œ≤ j)(x 1,‚ãØ,x r,x r+1,‚ãØx n)g 1(x 1)‚ãØg r(x r)j 1(x r+1)‚ãØj n(x n)dvol Œ£ n(x 1,‚ãØx n) ‚âîT(S 1,‚ãØ,S r,A r+1,‚ãØ,A n). \begin{aligned} & \underset{\Sigma^n}{\int} T_{(\alpha_i), (\beta_j)}(x_1, \cdots, x_{r}, x_{r+1}, \cdots x_{n}) g_1(x_1) \cdots g_r(x_r) \, j_1(x_{r+1}) \cdots j_n(x_n) \, dvol_{\Sigma^n}(x_1, \cdots x_n) \\ & \coloneqq T( S_1, \cdots, S_r, A_{r+1}, \cdots, A_n ) \end{aligned} \,.

Moreover, the subscripts on these generalized functions will always be clear from the context, so that in computations we may notationally suppress these.

Finally, due to the ‚Äúsymmetry‚Äù axiom in def. 10, a time-ordered product depends, up to signs, only on its set of arguments, not on the order of the arguments. We will write X‚âî{x 1,‚ãØ,x r}\mathbf{X} \coloneqq \{x_1, \cdots, x_r\} and Y‚âî{y 1,‚ãØy r}\mathbf{Y} \coloneqq \{y_1, \cdots y_r\} for sets of spacetime points, and hence abbreviate the expression for the ‚Äúvalue‚Äù of the generalized function in the above as T(X,Y)T(\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y}) etc.

In this condensed notation the above reads

‚à´Œ£ r+sT(X,Y)g 1(x 1)‚ãØg r(x r)j r+1(x r+1)‚ãØj n(x n)dvol Œ£ r+s(X). \underset{\Sigma^{r+s}}{\int} T(\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y}) \, g_1(x_1) \cdots g_r(x_r) j_{r+1}(x_{r+1}) \cdots j_n(x_n) \, dvol_{\Sigma^{r+s}}(\mathbf{X}) \,.

This condensed notation turns out to be greatly simplify computations, as it absorbs all the ‚Äúrelative‚Äù combinatorial prefactors:

Example

(product of perturbation series in generalized function-notation)

Let

U(g)‚âî‚àën=0‚àû1n!‚à´U(x 1,‚ãØ,x n)g(x 1)‚ãØg(x n)dvol U(g) \coloneqq \underoverset{n = 0}{\infty}{\sum} \frac{1}{n!} \int U(x_1, \cdots, x_n) \, g(x_1) \cdots g(x_n) \, dvol

and

V(g)‚âî‚àën=0‚àû1n!‚à´V(x 1,‚ãØ,x n)g(x 1)‚ãØg(x n)dvol V(g) \coloneqq \underoverset{n = 0}{\infty}{\sum} \frac{1}{n!} \int V(x_1, \cdots, x_n) \, g(x_1) \cdots g(x_n) \, dvol

be power series of Wick algebra-valued distributions in the generalized function-notation of remark 15.

Then their product W(g)‚âîU(g)V(g)W(g) \coloneqq U(g) V(g) with generalized function-representation

W(g)‚âî‚àën=0‚àû1n!‚à´W(x 1,‚ãØ,x n)g(x 1)‚ãØg(x n)dvol W(g) \coloneqq \underoverset{n = 0}{\infty}{\sum} \frac{1}{n!} \int W(x_1, \cdots, x_n) \, g(x_1) \cdots g(x_n) \, dvol

is given simply by

W(X)=‚àëI‚äÇXU(I)V(X‚àñI). W(\mathbf{X}) \;=\; \underset{\mathbf{I} \subset \mathbf{X}}{\sum} U(\mathbf{I}) V(\mathbf{X} \setminus \mathbf{I}) \,.

(Epstein-Glaser 73 (5))

Proof

For fixed cardinality |I|=n 1{\vert \mathbf{I} \vert} = n_1 the sum over all subsets I‚äÇX\mathbf{I} \subset \mathbf{X} overcounts the sum over partitions of the coordinates as (x 1,‚ãØx n 1,x n 1+1,‚ãØx n)(x_1, \cdots x_{n_1}, x_{n_1 + 1}, \cdots x_n) precisely by the binomial coefficient n!n 1!(n‚àín 1)!\frac{n!}{n_1! (n - n_1) !}. Here the factor of n!n! cancels against the ‚Äúglobal‚Äù combinatorial prefactor in the above expansion of W(g)W(g), while the remaining factor 1n 1!(n‚àín 1)!\frac{1}{n_1! (n - n_1) !} is just the ‚Äúrelative‚Äù combinatorial prefactor seen at total order nn when expanding the product U(g)V(g)U(g)V(g).

In order to prove that the axioms for time-ordered products do imply those for a perturbative S-matrix (prop. 9 below) we need to consider the corresponding reverse-time ordered products:

Definition

(reverse-time ordered products)

Given a time-ordered product T={T k} k‚àà‚ÑïT = \{T_k\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}} (def. 10), its reverse-time ordered product

T¬Ø k:(LocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]])‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST)((‚Ñè))[[g,j]] \overline{T}_k \;\colon\; \left( {\, \atop \,} LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [\hbar, g, j] ] {\, \atop \,} \right) \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})((\hbar))[ [g, j] ]

for k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N} is defined by

T¬Ø(A 1‚ãØA n)‚âî{‚àër=1n(‚àí1) r‚àëœÉ‚ààUnshuffl(n,r)T(A œÉ(1)‚ãØA œÉ(k 1))T(A œÉ(k 1+1)‚ãØA œÉ(k 2))‚ãØT(A œÉ(k r‚àí1+1)‚ãØA œÉ k r) | k‚â•1 1 | k=0, \overline{T}( A_1 \cdots A_n ) \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ \array{ \underoverset{r = 1}{n}{\sum} (-1)^r \underset{\sigma \in Unshuffl(n,r)}{\sum} T( A_{\sigma(1)} \cdots A_{\sigma(k_1)} ) \, T( A_{\sigma(k_1 + 1)} \cdots A_{\sigma(k_2)} ) \cdots T( A_{\sigma(k_{r-1}+1)} \cdots A_{\sigma_{k_r}} ) &\vert& k \geq 1 \\ 1 &\vert& k = 0 } \right. \,,

where the sum is over all unshuffles œÉ\sigma of (1‚â§‚ãØ‚â§n)(1 \leq \cdots \leq n) into rr non-empty ordered subsequences. Alternatively, in the generalized function-notation of remark 15, this reads

T¬Ø(X)=‚àër=1|X|(‚àí1) r‚àëI 1,‚ãØ,I r‚â†‚àÖ ‚àÄj‚â†k(I j‚à©I k=‚àÖ) I 1‚à™‚ãØ‚à™I r=XT(I 1)‚ãØT(I r) \overline{T}( \mathbf{X} ) = \underoverset{r = 1}{{\vert \mathbf{X} \vert}}{\sum} (-1)^r \underset{ \array{ \mathbf{I}_1, \cdots, \mathbf{I}_r \neq \emptyset \\ \underset{j \neq k}{\forall}\left( \mathbf{I}_j \cap \mathbf{I}_k = \emptyset \right) \\ \mathbf{I}_1 \cup \cdots \cup \mathbf{I}_r = \mathbf{X} } }{\sum} T( \mathbf{I}_1 ) \cdots T(\mathbf{I}_r)

(Epstein-Glaser 73, (11))

Proposition

(reverse-time ordered products express inverse S-matrix)

Given time-ordered products T(‚àí)T(-) (def. 10), then the corresponding reverse time-ordered product T¬Ø(‚àí)\overline{T}(-) (def. 11) expresses the inverse S(‚àí) ‚àí1S(-)^{-1} (according to remark 2) of the corresponding perturbative S-matrix scheme ùíÆ(S int)‚âî‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï1k!T(S int,‚ãØ,S int‚èükargs)\mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \coloneqq \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \tfrac{1}{k!} T(\underset{k\,\text{args}}{\underbrace{S_{int}, \cdots , S_{int}}}) (def. 3):

(ùíÆ(gS int+jA)) ‚àí1=‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï1k!(1i‚Ñè) kT¬Ø((gS int+jA),‚ãØ,(gS int+jA)‚èükarguments). \left( {\, \atop \,} \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A ) {\, \atop \,} \right)^{-1} \;=\; \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \frac{1}{k!} \left( \frac{1}{i \hbar} \right)^k \overline{T}( \underset{k \, \text{arguments}}{\underbrace{ (g S_{int} + j A), \cdots, (g S_{int} + j A)}} ) \,.
Proof

For brevity we write just ‚ÄúAA‚Äù for 1i‚Ñè(gS int+jA)\tfrac{1}{i \hbar}(g S_{int} + j A). (Hence we assume without restriction that AA is not independent of powers of gg and jj; this is just for making all sums in the following be order-wise finite sums.)

By definition we have

‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï1k!T¬Ø(A,‚ãØ,A‚èükargs) =‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï1k!‚àër=1k(‚àí1) r‚àëœÉ‚ààUnshuffl(k,r)T(A œÉ(1)‚ãØA œÉ(k 1))T(A œÉ(k 1+1)‚ãØA œÉ(k 2))‚ãØT(A œÉ(k r‚àí1+1)‚ãØA œÉ k r) \begin{aligned} & \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \frac{1}{k!} \overline{T}( \underset{k \, \text{args}}{\underbrace{A, \cdots , A}} ) \\ & = \underset{ k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \frac{1}{k!} \underoverset{r = 1}{k}{\sum} (-1)^r \!\!\!\underset{\sigma \in Unshuffl(k,r)}{\sum}\!\!\! T( A_{\sigma(1)} \cdots A_{\sigma(k_1)} ) T( A_{\sigma(k_1 + 1)} \cdots A_{\sigma(k_2)} ) \cdots T( A_{\sigma(k_{r-1}+1)} \cdots A_{\sigma_{k_r}} ) \end{aligned}

where all the A kA_k happen to coincide: A k=AA_k = A.

If instead of unshuffles (i.e. partitions into non-empty subsequences preserving the original order) we took partitions into arbitrarily ordered subsequences, we would be overcounting by the factorial of the length of the subsequences, and hence the above may be equivalently written as:

‚ãØ=‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï1k!‚àër=1k(‚àí1) r‚àëœÉ‚ààŒ£(k)k 1+‚ãØ+k r=k‚àÄi(k i‚â•1)1k 1!‚ãØ1k r!T(A œÉ(1)‚ãØA œÉ(k 1))T(A œÉ(k 1+1)‚ãØA œÉ(k 2))‚ãØT(A œÉ(k r‚àí1+1)‚ãØA œÉ k r), \cdots = \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \tfrac{1}{k!} \underoverset{r = 1}{k}{\sum} (-1)^r \!\!\! \underset{ {\sigma \in \Sigma(k)} \atop { { k_1 + \cdots + k_r = k } \atop { \underset{i}{\forall} (k_i \geq 1) } } }{\sum} \!\!\! \tfrac{1}{k_1!} \cdots \tfrac{1}{k_r !} \, T( A_{\sigma(1)} \cdots A_{\sigma(k_1)} ) \, T( A_{\sigma(k_1 + 1)} \cdots A_{\sigma(k_2)} ) \cdots T( A_{\sigma(k_{r-1}+1)} \cdots A_{\sigma_{k_r}} ) \,,

where Œ£(k)\Sigma(k) denotes the symmetric group (the set of all permutations of kk elements).

Moreover, since all the A kA_k are equal, the sum is in fact independent of œÉ\sigma, it only depends on the length of the subsequences. Since there are k!k! permutations of kk elements the above reduces to

‚ãØ =‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï‚àër=1k(‚àí1) r‚àëk 1+‚ãØ+k r=k1k 1!‚ãØ1k r!T(A,‚ãØ,A‚èük 1factors)T(A,‚ãØ,A‚èük 2factors)‚ãØT(A,‚ãØ,A‚èük rfactors) =‚àër=0‚àû(‚àí‚àëk=0‚àûT(A,‚ãØ,A‚èükfactors)) r =ùíÆ(A) ‚àí1, \begin{aligned} \cdots & = \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \underoverset{r = 1}{k}{\sum} (-1)^r \!\!\! \underset{ k_1 + \cdots + k_r = k }{\sum} \tfrac{1}{k_1!} \cdots \tfrac{1}{k_r !} T( \underset{k_1 \, \text{factors}}{\underbrace{ A, \cdots , A }} ) T( \underset{k_2 \, \text{factors}}{\underbrace{ A, \cdots , A }} ) \cdots T( \underset{k_r \, \text{factors}}{\underbrace{ A, \cdots , A }} ) \\ & = \underoverset{r = 0}{\infty}{\sum} \left( - \underoverset{k = 0}{\infty}{\sum} T ( \underset{k\,\text{factors}}{\underbrace{A, \cdots , A}} ) \right)^r \\ & = \mathcal{S}(A)^{-1} \,, \end{aligned}

where in the last line we used (6).

In fact prop. 6 is a special case of the following more general statement:

Proposition

(inversion relation for reverse-time ordered products)

Let {T k} k‚àà‚Ñï\{T_k\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}} be time-ordered products according to def. 10. Then the reverse-time ordered products according to def. 11 satisfies the following inversion relation for all X‚â†‚àÖ\mathbf{X} \neq \emptyset (in the condensed notation of remark 15):

‚àëJ‚äÇXT(J)T¬Ø(X‚àñJ)=0 \underset{\mathbf{J} \subset \mathbf{X}}{\sum} T(\mathbf{J}) \overline{T}(\mathbf{X} \setminus \mathbf{J}) \;=\; 0

and

‚àëJ‚äÇXT¬Ø(X‚àñJ)T(J)=0 \underset{\mathbf{J} \subset \mathbf{X}}{\sum} \overline{T}(\mathbf{X} \setminus \mathbf{J}) T(\mathbf{J}) \;=\; 0
Proof

This is immediate from unwinding the definitions.

Proposition

(reverse causal factorization of reverse-time ordered products)

Let {T k} k‚àà‚Ñï\{T_k\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}} be time-ordered products according to def. 10. Then the reverse-time ordered products according to def. 11 satisfies reverse-causal factorization.

(Epstein-Glaser 73, around (15))

Proof

In the condensed notation of remark 15, we need to show that for X=P‚à™Q\mathbf{X} = \mathbf{P} \cup \mathbf{Q} with P‚à©Q=‚àÖ\mathbf{P} \cap \mathbf{Q} = \emptyset then

(P‚à®‚àßQ)‚áí(T¬Ø(X)=T¬Ø(Q)T¬Ø(P)). \left( \mathbf{P} {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \mathbf{Q} \right) \;\Rightarrow\; \left( \overline{T}(\mathbf{X}) = \overline{T}(\mathbf{Q}) \overline{T}(\mathbf{P}) \right) \,.

We proceed by induction. If |X|=1{\vert \mathbf{X}\vert} = 1 the statement is immediate. So assume that the statement is true for sets of cardinality n‚â•1n \geq 1 and consider X\mathbf{X} with |X|=n+1{\vert \mathbf{X}\vert} = n+1.

We make free use of the condensed notation as in example 4.

From the formal inversion

‚àëJ‚äÇXT¬Ø(J)T(X‚àñJ)=0 \underset{\mathbf{J} \subset \mathbf{X}}{\sum} \overline{T}(\mathbf{J}) T(\mathbf{X}\setminus \mathbf{J}) = 0

(which uses the induction assumption that |X|‚â•1{\vert \mathbf{X}\vert} \geq 1) it follows that

T¬Ø(X) =‚àí‚àëJ‚äÇXJ‚â†XT¬Ø(J)T(X‚àñJ) =‚àí‚àëJ‚à™J‚Ä≤=XJ‚à©J‚Ä≤=‚àÖJ‚Ä≤‚â†‚àÖT¬Ø(Q‚à©J)T¬Ø(P‚à©J)T(P‚à©(J‚Ä≤))T(Q‚à©(J‚Ä≤)) =‚àí‚àëL‚à™L‚Ä≤=Q,L‚à©L‚Ä≤=‚àÖL‚Ä≤‚â†‚àÖT¬Ø(L)(‚àëK‚äÇPT¬Ø(K)T(P‚àñK))‚èü=0T(L‚Ä≤)‚àíT¬Ø(Q)‚àëK‚äÇPK‚â†‚àÖT¬Ø(K)T(P‚àñK)‚èü=‚àíT¬Ø(P) =T¬Ø(Q)T¬Ø(P). \begin{aligned} \overline{T}(\mathbf{X}) & = - \underset{ { \mathbf{J} \subset \mathbf{X} } \atop { \mathbf{J} \neq \mathbf{X} } }{\sum} \overline{T}(\mathbf{J}) T( \mathbf{X} \setminus \mathbf{J} ) \\ & = - \underset{ { \mathbf{J} \cup \mathbf{J}' = \mathbf{X} } \atop { { \mathbf{J} \cap \mathbf{J}' = \emptyset } \atop { \mathbf{J}' \neq \emptyset } } }{\sum} \overline{T}( \mathbf{Q} \cap \mathbf{J} ) \overline{T}( \mathbf{P} \cap \mathbf{J} ) T ( \mathbf{P} \cap ( \mathbf{J}' ) ) T ( \mathbf{Q} \cap ( \mathbf{J}' ) ) \\ & = - \underset{ { \mathbf{L} \cup \mathbf{L}' = \mathbf{Q} \,,\, \mathbf{L} \cap \mathbf{L}' = \emptyset } \atop { \mathbf{L}' \neq \emptyset } }{\sum} \!\!\! \overline{T}( \mathbf{L} ) \underset{ = 0}{ \underbrace{ \left( \underset{ \mathbf{K} \subset \mathbf{P} }{\sum} \overline{T}( \mathbf{K} ) T( \mathbf{P} \setminus \mathbf{K}) \right) } } T(\mathbf{L'}) - \overline{T}(\mathbf{Q}) \underset{ = - \overline{T}(\mathbf{P}) }{ \underbrace{ \underset{ {\mathbf{K} \subset \mathbf{P}} \atop { \mathbf{K} \neq \emptyset } }{\sum} \overline{T}(\mathbf{K}) T (\mathbf{P} \setminus \mathbf{K} ) }} \\ & = \overline{T}(\mathbf{Q}) \overline{T}(\mathbf{P}) \end{aligned} \,.

Here

  1. in the second line we used that X=Q‚äîP\mathbf{X} = \mathbf{Q} \sqcup \mathbf{P}, together with the causal factorization property of T(‚àí)T(-) (which holds by def. 10) and that of T¬Ø(‚àí)\overline{T}(-) (which holds by the induction assumption, using that J‚â†X\mathbf{J} \neq \mathbf{X} hence that |J|<|X|{\vert \mathbf{J}\vert} \lt {\vert \mathbf{X}\vert}).

  2. in the third line we decomposed the sum over J,J‚Ä≤‚äÇX\mathbf{J}, \mathbf{J}' \subset \mathbf{X} into two sums over subsets of Q\mathbf{Q} and P\mathbf{P}:

    1. The first summand in the third line is the contribution where J‚Ä≤\mathbf{J}' has a non-empty intersection with Q\mathbf{Q}. This makes K\mathbf{K} range without constraint, and therefore the sum in the middle vanishes, as indicated, as it is the contribution at order |Q|{\vert \mathbf{Q}\vert} of the inversion formula from prop. 7.

    2. The second summand in the third line is the contribution where J‚Ä≤\mathbf{J}' does not intersect Q\mathbf{Q}. Now the sum over K\mathbf{K} is the inversion formula from prop. 7 except for one term, and so it equals that term.

Using these facts about the reverse-time ordered products, we may finally prove that time-ordered products indeed do induced a perturbative S-matrix:

Proposition

(time-ordered products induce S-matrix)

Let {T k} k‚àà‚Ñï\{T_k\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}} be a system of time-ordered products according to def. 10. Then

ùíÆ(‚àí) ‚âîT(exp ‚äó(1i‚Ñè(‚àí))) ‚âî‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï1k!1(i‚Ñè) kT(‚àí,‚ãØ,‚àí‚èükfactors) \begin{aligned} \mathcal{S}(-) & \coloneqq T \left( \exp_\otimes \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar}(-) \right) \right) \\ & \coloneqq \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \tfrac{1}{k!} \tfrac{1}{(i \hbar)^k} T( \underset{k \, \text{factors}}{\underbrace{-, \cdots , -}} ) \end{aligned}

is indeed a perturbative S-matrix according to def. 3.

Proof

The axiom ‚Äúperturbation‚Äù of the S-matrix is immediate from the axioms ‚Äúperturbation‚Äù and ‚Äúnormalization‚Äù of the time-ordered products. What requires proof is that causal additivity of the S-matrix follows from the causal factorization property of the time-ordered products.

Notice that also the weaker causal factorization property of the S-matrix (remark 6) is immediate from the causal factorization condition on the time-ordered products.

But causal additivity is stronger. It is remarkable that this, too, follows from just the time-ordering (Epstein-Glaser 73, around (73)):

To see this, first expand the generating function ùíµ\mathcal{Z} (7) into powers of gg and jj

ùíµ gS int(jA)=‚àën,m=0‚àû1n!m!R(gS int,‚ãØ,gS int‚èünfactors,(jA,‚ãØ,jA‚èümfactors)) \mathcal{Z}_{g S_{int}}(j A) \;=\; \underoverset{n,m = 0}{\infty}{\sum} \frac{1}{n! m!} R\left( {\, \atop \,} \underset{n\, \text{factors}}{\underbrace{g S_{int}, \cdots ,g S_{int}}}, ( \underset{m \, \text{factors}}{ \underbrace{ j A , \cdots , j A } } ) {\, \atop \,} \right)

and then compare order-by-order with the given time-ordered product TT and its induced reverse-time ordered product (def. 11) via prop. 6. (These R(‚àí,‚àí)R(-,-) are also called the ‚Äúgenerating retarded products, discussed in their own right around def. \ref{RetardedProductFromPerturbativeSMatrix} below.)

In the condensed notation of remark 15 and its way of absorbing combinatorial prefactors as in example 4 this yields at order (g/‚Ñè) |Y|(j/‚Ñè) |X|(g/\hbar)^{\vert \mathbf{Y}\vert} (j/\hbar)^{\vert \mathbf{X}\vert} the coefficient

(13)R(Y,X)=‚àëI‚äÇYT¬Ø(I)T((Y‚àñI),X). R(\mathbf{Y}, \mathbf{X}) \;=\; \underset{\mathbf{I} \subset \mathbf{Y}}{\sum} \overline{T}(\mathbf{I}) T( (\mathbf{Y} \setminus \mathbf{I}) , \mathbf{X} ) \,.

We claim now that the support of RR is inside the subset for which Y\mathbf{Y} is in the causal past of X\mathbf{X}. This will imply the claim, because by multi-linearity of R(‚àí,‚àí)R(-,-) it then follows that

(supp(A 1)‚à®‚àßsupp(A 2))‚áí(Z (gS int+jA 1)(jA 2)=Z S int(A 2)) \left(supp(A_1) {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} supp(A_2)\right) \Rightarrow \left( Z_{(g S_{int} + j A_1)}(j A_2) = Z_{S_{int}}(A_2) \right)

and by prop. 1 this is equivalent to causal additivity of the S-matrix.

It remains to prove the claim:

Consider X,Y‚äÇŒ£\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \subset \Sigma such that the subset P‚äÇY\mathbf{P} \subset \mathbf{Y} of points not in the past of X\mathbf{X}, hence the maximal subset with causal ordering

P‚à®‚àßX, \mathbf{P} {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \mathbf{X} \,,

is non-empty. We need to show that in this case R(Y,X)=0R(\mathbf{Y}, \mathbf{X}) = 0 (in the sense of generalized functions).

Write Q‚âîY‚àñP\mathbf{Q} \coloneqq \mathbf{Y} \setminus \mathbf{P} for the complementary set of points, so that all points of Q\mathbf{Q} are in the past of X\mathbf{X}. Notice that this implies that P\mathbf{P} is also not in the past of Q\mathbf{Q}:

P‚à®‚àßQ. \mathbf{P} {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \mathbf{Q} \,.

With this decomposition of Y\mathbf{Y}, the sum in (13) over subsets I\mathbf{I} of Y\mathbf{Y} may be decomposed into a sum over subsets J\mathbf{J} of P\mathbf{P} and K\mathbf{K} of Q\mathbf{Q}, respectively. These subsets inherit the above causal ordering, so that by the causal factorization property of T(‚àí)T(-) (def. 10) and T¬Ø(‚àí)\overline{T}(-) (prop. 8) the time-ordered and reverse time-ordered products factor on these arguments:

R(Y,X) =‚àëJ‚äÇPK‚äÇQT¬Ø(J‚à™K)T((P‚àñJ)‚à™(Q‚àñK),X) =‚àëJ‚äÇPK‚äÇQT¬Ø(K)T¬Ø(J)T(P‚àñJ)T(Q‚àñK,X) =‚àëK‚äÇQT¬Ø(K)(‚àëJ‚äÇPT¬Ø(J)T(P‚àñJ))‚èü=0T(Q‚àñK,X). \begin{aligned} R(\mathbf{Y}, \mathbf{X}) & = \underset{ {\mathbf{J} \subset \mathbf{P}} \atop { \mathbf{K} \subset \mathbf{Q} } }{\sum} \, \overline{T}( \mathbf{J} \cup \mathbf{K} ) T( (\mathbf{P} \setminus \mathbf{J}) \cup (\mathbf{Q} \setminus \mathbf{K}), \mathbf{X} ) \\ & = \underset{ {\mathbf{J} \subset \mathbf{P}} \atop { \mathbf{K} \subset \mathbf{Q} } }{\sum} \, \overline{T}( \mathbf{K} ) \overline{T}( \mathbf{J} ) T( \mathbf{P} \setminus \mathbf{J} ) T( \mathbf{Q} \setminus \mathbf{K}, \mathbf{X} ) \\ & = \underset{ \mathbf{K} \subset \mathbf{Q} }{\sum} \overline{T}(\mathbf{K}) \underset{= 0}{ \underbrace{ \left( \underset{\mathbf{J} \subset \mathbf{P}}{\sum} \overline{T}(\mathbf{J}) T( \mathbf{P} \setminus \mathbf{J} ) \right) }} T(\mathbf{Q} \setminus \mathbf{K}, \mathbf{X}) \end{aligned} \,.

Here the sub-sum in brackets vanishes by the inversion formula, prop. 7.

\,

(‚ÄúRe‚Äù-)Normalization

We discuss now that time-ordered products as in def. 10, hence, by prop. 9, perturbative S-matrix schemes (def. 3) exist in fact uniquely away from coinciding interaction points (prop. 10 below).

This means that the construction of full time-ordered products/S-matrix schemes may be phrased as an extension of distributions of time-ordered products to the diagonal locus of coinciding spacetime arguments (prop. 11 below). This choice in their definition is called the choice of ("re"-)normalization of the time-ordered products (remark 11), and hence of the interacting pQFT that these define (def. 16 below).

The space of these choices may be accurately characterized, it is a torsor over a group of re-definitions of the interaction-terms, called the ‚ÄúSt√ºckelberg-Petermann renormalization group‚Äù. This is called the main theorem of perturbative renormalization, theorem 1 below.

Here we discuss just enough of the ingredients needed to state this theorem. For proof of theorem and discussion of the various methods of picking ("re"-)normalizations see there.

\,

Definition

(tuples of local observables with pairwise disjoint spacetime support)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

For k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N}, write

(LocPoly(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]) pds ‚äó ‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]] k‚Ü™(LocPoly(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]) ‚äó ‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]] k \left( {\, \atop \,} LocPoly(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, j ] ] {\, \atop \,} \right)^{\otimes^k_{\mathbb{C}[ [\hbar, g, j ] ]}}_{pds} \hookrightarrow \left( {\, \atop \,} LocPoly(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, j ] ] {\, \atop \,} \right)^{\otimes^k_{\mathbb{C}[ [\hbar, g, j ] ]}}

for the linear subspace of the kk-fold tensor product of local observables (as in def. 3, def. 10) on those tensor products A 1‚äó‚ãØA kA_1 \otimes \cdots A_k of tuples with disjoint spacetime support:

supp(A j)‚à©supp(A k)=‚àÖAAAfori‚â†j‚àà{1,‚ãØ,k}. supp(A_j) \cap supp(A_k) = \emptyset \phantom{AAA} \text{for} \, i \neq j \in \{1, \cdots, k\} \,.
Proposition

(time-ordered product unique away from coinciding spacetime arguments)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, and let T={T k} k‚àà‚ÑïT = \{T_k\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}} be a sequence of time-ordered products (def. 10)

(LocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]) ‚äó ‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]] k ‚ü∂ PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg((‚Ñè))[[g,j]] ‚Üë ‚Üó (‚àí)‚ãÜ F‚ãØ‚ãÜ F(‚àí) (LocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]) pds ‚äó ‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]] k \array{ \left( {\, \atop \,} LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [\hbar, g, j] ] {\, \atop \,} \right)^{\otimes^k_{\mathbb{C}[ [\hbar, g, j] ]}} & \longrightarrow & PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}((\hbar))[ [g , j] ] \\ \uparrow & \nearrow_{(-) \star_F \cdots \star_F (-)} \\ \left( {\, \atop \,} LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [\hbar, g, j] ] {\, \atop \,} \right)^{\otimes^k_{\mathbb{C}[ [\hbar, g, j] ]}}_{pds} }

Then their restriction to the subspace of tuples of local observables of pairwise disjoint spacetime support (def. 12) is unique (independent of the "re-"normalization freedom in choosing TT) and is given by the star product

A 1‚ãÜ FA 2‚âî((‚àí)‚ãÖ(‚àí))‚àòexp(‚Ñè(‚à´Œ£√óŒ£Œî F ab(x,y)Œ¥Œ¥Œ¶ a(x)‚äóŒ¥Œ¥Œ¶ b(y)dvol Œ£(x)dvol Œ£(y)))(A 1‚äóA 2) A_1 \star_{F} A_2 \;\coloneqq\; ((-)\cdot (-)) \circ \exp\left( \hbar \left( \underset{\Sigma \times \Sigma}{\int} \Delta_F^{a b}(x,y) \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}^a(x)} \otimes \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}^b(y)} \, dvol_\Sigma(x)\, dvol_\Sigma(y) \right) \right) (A_1 \otimes A_2)

that is induced (def. \ref{PropagatorStarProduct}) by the Feynman propagator Œî F‚âîi2(Œî ++Œî ‚àí+H)\Delta_F \coloneqq \tfrac{i}{2}(\Delta_+ + \Delta_- + H) (corresponding to the Wightman propagator Œî H=i2(Œî +‚àíŒî ‚àí)+H\Delta_H = \tfrac{i}{2}(\Delta_+ - \Delta_-) + H which is given by the choice of free vacuum), in that

T(A 1,‚ãØ,A k)=A 1‚ãÜ F‚ãØ‚ãÜ FA k. T \left( {\, \atop \,} A_1 , \cdots, A_k {\, \atop \,} \right) \;=\; A_1 \star_F \cdots \star_F A_k \,.

In particular the time-ordered product extends from the restricted domain of tensor products of local observables to a restricted domain of microcausal polynomial observables, where it becomes an associative product:

(14)T(A 1,‚ãØ,A k n) =T(A 1,‚ãØ,A k 1)‚ãÜ FT(A k 1+1,‚ãØ,A k 2)‚ãÜ F‚ãØ‚ãÜ FT(A k n‚àí1+1,‚ãØ,A k n) =A 1‚ãÜ F‚ãØ‚ãÜ FA k n \begin{aligned} T(A_1, \cdots, A_{k_n}) & = T(A_1, \cdots, A_{k_1}) \star_F T(A_{k_1 + 1}, \cdots, A_{k_2}) \star_F \cdots \star_F T(A_{k_{n-1} + 1}, \cdots, A_{k_n}) \\ & = A_1 \star_F \cdots \star_F A_{k_n} \end{aligned}

for all tuples of local observables A 1,‚ãØ,A k 1,A k 1+1,‚ãØ,A k 2,‚ãØ,‚ãØA k nA_1, \cdots, A_{k_1}, A_{k_1+1}, \cdots, A_{k_2}, \cdots, \cdots A_{k_n} with pairwise disjoint spacetime support.

The idea of this statement goes back at least to Epstein-Glaser 73, as in remark 10. One formulation appears as (Brunetti-Fredenhagen 00, theorem 4.3). The above formulation in terms of the star product is stated in (Fredenhagen-Rejzner 12, p. 27, D√ºtsch 18, lemma 3.63 (b)).

Proof

By induction over the number of arguments, it is sufficient to see that, more generally, for A 1,A 2‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST) mc[[‚Ñè,g,j]]A_1, A_2 \in PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{mc}[ [ \hbar, g, j] ] two microcausal polynomial observables with disjoint spacetime support the star product A 1‚ãÜ FA 2A_1 \star_F A_2 is well-defined and satisfies causal factorization.

Consider two partitions of unity

(œá 1,i‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)) iAAA(œá 1,j‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)) j (\chi_{1,i} \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma))_{i} \phantom{AAA} (\chi_{1,j} \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma))_{j}

and write (A 1,i) i(A_{1,i})_i and (A 2,j) j(A_{2,j})_{j} for the collection of microcausal polynomial observables obtained by multiplying all the distributional coefficients of A 1A_1 and of A 2A_2 with œá 1,i\chi_{1,i} and with œá 2,j\chi_{2,j}, respectively, for all ii and jj, hence such that

A 1=‚àëiA 1,iAAAA 2=‚àëjA 1,j. A_1 \;=\; \underset{i}{\sum} A_{1,i} \phantom{AAA} A_2 \;=\; \underset{j}{\sum} A_{1,j} \,.

By linearity, it is sufficient to prove that A 1,i‚ãÜ FA 2,jA_{1,i} \star_F A_{2,j} is well defined for all i,ji,j and satisfies causal factorization.

Since the spacetime supports of A 1A_1 and A 2A_2 are assumed to be disjoint

supp(A 1)‚à©supp(A 2)=‚àÖ supp(A_1) \cap supp(A_2) \;=\; \emptyset

we may find partitions such that each resulting pair of smaller supports is in fact in causal order-relation:

(supp(A 1)‚à©supp(œá 1,i))‚à®‚àß(supp(A 2)‚à©supp(œá 2,j)) or (supp(A 2)‚à©supp(œá 2,j))‚à®‚àß(supp(A 1)‚à©supp(œá 1,u))AAAAAfor alli,j. \array{ \left( supp(A_1) \cap supp(\chi_{1,i}) \right) {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \left( supp(A_2) \cap supp(\chi_{2,j}) \right) \\ \text{or} \\ \left( supp(A_2) \cap supp(\chi_{2,j}) \right) {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \left( supp(A_1) \cap supp(\chi_{1,u}) \right) } \phantom{AAAAA} \text{for all}\,\, i,j \,.

But now it follows as in the proof of prop. \ref{CausalOrderingTimeOrderedProductOnRegular}) via (eq:CausallyOrderedWickProductViaFeynmanPropagator) that

A 1,i‚ãÜ FA 2,j={A 1,i‚ãÜ HA 2,j | supp(A 1,i)‚à®‚àßsupp(A 2,j) A 2,j‚ãÜ HA 1,i | supp(A 2,j)‚à®‚àßsupp(A 1,i) A_{1,i} \star_F A_{2,j} \;=\; \left\{ \array{ A_{1,i} \star_H A_{2,j} &\vert& supp(A_{1,i}) {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} supp(A_{2,j}) \\ A_{2,j} \star_H A_{1,i} &\vert& supp(A_{2,j}) {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} supp(A_{1,i}) } \right.

Finally the associativity-statement follows as in prop. \ref{AssociativeAndUnitalStarProduct}.

Before using the unqueness of the time-ordered products away from coinciding spacetime arguments (prop. 10) to characterize the freedom in ("re"-)normalizing time-ordered products, we pause to observe that in the same vein the time-ordered products have a unique extension of their domain also to regular polynomial observables. This is in itself a trivial statement (since all star products are defined on regular polynomial observables, def. \ref{PropagatorStarProduct}) but for understanding the behaviour under ("re"-)normalization of other structures, such as the interacting BV-differential (def. 25 below) it is useful to understand renormalization as a process that starts extending awa from regular polynomial observables.

By prop. 15, on regular polynomial observables the S-matrix is given as follows:

Definition

(perturbative S-matrix on regular polynomial observables)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

Recall that the time-ordered product on regular polynomial observables is the star product ‚ãÜ F\star_F induced by the Feynman propagator (def. \ref{OnRegularPolynomialObservablesTimeOrderedProduct}) and that, due to the non-singular nature of regular polynomial observables, this is given by conjugation of the pointwise product (eq:ObservablesPointwiseProduct) with ùíØ\mathcal{T} (eq:OnRegularPolynomialObservablesPointwiseTimeOrderedIsomorphism) as

T(A 1,A 2)=A 1‚ãÜ FA 2=ùíØ(ùíØ ‚àí1(A 1)‚ãÖùíØ ‚àí1(A 2)) T(A_1, A_2) \;=\; A_1 \star_F A_2 \;=\; \mathcal{T}( \mathcal{T}^{-1}(A_1) \cdot \mathcal{T}^{-1}(A_2))

(prop. \ref{IsomorphismOnRegularPolynomialObservablesTimeOrderedandPointwise}).

We say that the perturbative S-matrix scheme on regular polynomial observables is the exponential with respect to ‚ãÜ F\star_F:

ùíÆ:PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg((‚Ñè))[[g,j]] \mathcal{S} \;\colon\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}[ [\hbar, g , j] ] \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}((\hbar))[ [ g, j] ]

given by

ùíÆ(S int)=exp ‚ãÜ F(1i‚ÑèS int))‚âî1+1i‚ÑèS int+121(i‚Ñè) 2S int‚ãÜ FS int+‚ãØ. \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) = \exp_{\star_F} \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int}) \right) \coloneqq 1 + \tfrac{1}{\i \hbar} S_{int} + \tfrac{1}{2} \tfrac{1}{(i \hbar)^2} S_{int} \star_F S_{int} + \cdots \,.

We think of S intS_{int} here as an adiabatically switched non-point-interaction action functional.

We write ùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1\mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1} for the inverse with respect to the Wick product (which exists by remark 2)

ùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1‚ãÜ HùíÆ(S int)=1. \mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1} \star_H \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) = 1 \,.

Notice that this is in general different form the inverse with respect to the time-ordered product ‚ãÜ F\star_F, which is ùíÆ(‚àíS int)\mathcal{S}(-S_{int}):

ùíÆ(‚àíS int)‚ãÜ FùíÆ(S int)=1. \mathcal{S}(-S_{int}) \star_F \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) = 1 \,.

Similarly, by def. 7, on regular polynomial observables the quantum M√∏ller operator is given as follows:

Definition

(quantum M√∏ller operator on regular polynomial observables)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1. Given an adiabatically switched non-point-interaction action functional in the form of a regular polynomial observable of degree 0

S int‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg[[‚Ñè,g,j]] S_{int} \;\in\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}[ [\hbar , g, j] ]

then the corresponding quantum M√∏ller operator on regular polynomial observables

‚Ñõ ‚àí1:PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg[[‚Ñè,g,j]] \mathcal{R}^{-1} \;\colon\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}[ [\hbar , g, j] ] \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}[ [\hbar, g, j] ]

is given by the derivative of Bogoliubov's formula

‚Ñõ ‚àí1‚âîùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1‚ãÜ H(ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ F(‚àí)), \mathcal{R}^{-1} \;\coloneqq\; \mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1} \star_H (\mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F (-)) \,,

where ùíÆ(S int)=exp ùíØ(‚àí1i‚ÑèS int)\mathcal{S}(S_{int}) = \exp_{\mathcal{T}}\left( \tfrac{-1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) is the perturbative S-matrix from def. 13.

This indeed lands in formal power series in Planck's constant ‚Ñè\hbar (by remark \ref{PowersInPlancksConstant}), instead of in more general Laurent series as the perturbative S-matrix does (def. 13).

Hence the inverse map is

‚Ñõ=ùíÆ(‚àíS int)‚ãÜ F(ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ(‚àí)). \mathcal{R} \;=\; \mathcal{S}(-S_{int}) \star_F ( \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star(-) ) \,.

(Bogoliubov-Shirkov 59; the above terminology follows Hawkins-Rejzner 16, below def. 5.1)

(Beware that compared to Fredenhagen, Rejzner et. al. we change notation conventions ‚Ñõ‚Üî‚Ñõ ‚àí1\mathcal{R} \leftrightarrow \mathcal{R}^{-1} in order to bring out the analogy to (the conventions for the) time-ordered product A 1‚ãÜ FA 2=ùíØ(ùíØ ‚àí1(A 1)‚ãÖùíØ ‚àí1(A 2))A_1 \star_F A_2 = \mathcal{T}(\mathcal{T}^{-1}(A_1) \cdot \mathcal{T}^{-1}(A_2)) on regular polynomial observables.)

Still by def. 7, on regular polynomial observables the interacting field algebra of observables is given as follows:

Definition

(interacting field algebra structure on regular polynomial observables)

then the interacting field algebra structure on regular polynomial observables

is the conjugation of the Wick algebra-structure by the quantum M√∏ller operator (def. 14):

A 1‚ãÜ intA 2‚âî‚Ñõ(‚Ñõ ‚àí1(A 1)‚ãÜ H‚Ñõ ‚àí1(A 2)) A_1 \star_{int} A_2 \;\coloneqq\; \mathcal{R} \left( \mathcal{R}^{-1}(A_1) \star_H \mathcal{R}^{-1}(A_2) \right)

(e.g. Fredenhagen-Rejzner 11b, (19))

After having discussed the uniqueness of the time-ordered products away from coinciding spacetime arguments (prop. 10) we now phrase and then discuss the freedom in defining these products at coinciding arguments, thus ("re"-)normalizing them.

Definition

(("re"-)normalization of perturbative QFT)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

Prop. 10 implies that the problem of constructing a sequence of time-ordered products (def. 10), hence, by prop. 9, an S-matrix scheme (def. 3) for perturbative quantum field theory around the given free field vacuum, is equivalently a problem of a sequence of compatible extensions of distributions of the star products (‚àí)‚ãÜ F‚ãØ‚ãÜ F(‚àí)‚èükarguments\underset{k \; \text{arguments}}{\underbrace{(-)\star_F \cdots \star_F (-)}} of the Feynman propagator on kk arguments from the complement of coinciding events inside the Cartesian products Œ£ k\Sigma^k of spacetime Œ£\Sigma, along the canonical inclusion

Œ£ k‚àñ{(x i)|‚àÉi‚â†j(x i=x j)}‚Ü™AAAŒ£ k. \Sigma^k \setminus \left\{ (x_i) \,\vert\, \underset{i \neq j}{\exists} (x_i = x_j) \right\} \overset{\phantom{AAA}}{\hookrightarrow} \Sigma^k \,.

Via the associativity (14) of the restricted time-ordered product thesese choices are naturally made by induction over kk, choosing the (k+1)(k+1)-ary time-ordered product T k+1T_{k+1} as an extension of distributions of T k(‚àí,‚ãØ,‚àí‚èükargs)‚ãÜ F(‚àí)T_k(\underset{k \, \text{args}}{\underbrace{-, \cdots, -}}) \star_F (-).

This inductive choice of extension of distributions of the time-ordered product to coinciding interaction points deserves to be called a choice of normalization of the time-ordered product (e.g. Scharf 94, section 4.3), but for historical reasons (see remark 10 and remark 11) it is known as re-normalization.

In (Epstein-Glaser 73) this is phrased in terms of splitting of distributions. In (Brunetti-Fredenhagen 00, sections 4 and 7) the perspective via extension of distributions is introduced, following (Stora 93). Review is in (D√ºtsch 18, section 3.3.2).

Proposition 10 already shows that the freedom in choosing the ("re"-)normalization of time-ordered products is at most that of extending them to the ‚Äúfat diagonal‚Äù, where at least one pair of interaction points coincides. The following proposition 11 says that when making these choices inductively in the arity of the time-ordered products as in def. 16 then the available choice of ("re"-)normalization) at each stage is in fact only that of extension to the actual diagonal, where all interaction points coincide:

Proposition

(("re"-)normalization is inductive extension of time-ordered products to diagonal)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

Assume that for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, time-ordered products {T k} k‚â§n\{T_{k}\}_{k \leq n} of arity k‚â§nk \leq n have been constructed in the sense of def. 10. Then the time-ordered product T n+1T_{n+1} of arity n+1n+1 is uniquely fixed on the complement

Œ£ n+1‚àñdiag(n)={(x i‚ààŒ£) i=1 n|‚àÉi,j(x i‚â†x j)} \Sigma^{n+1} \setminus diag(n) \;=\; \left\{ (x_i \in \Sigma)_{i = 1}^n \;\vert\; \underset{i,j}{\exists} (x_i \neq x_j) \right\}

of the image of the diagonal inclusion Œ£‚ü∂diagŒ£ n\Sigma \overset{diag}{\longrightarrow} \Sigma^{n} (where we regarded T n+1T_{n+1} as a generalized function on Œ£ n+1\Sigma^{n+1} according to remark 15).

This statement appears in (Popineau-Stora 82), with (unpublished) details in (Stora 93), following personal communication by Henri Epstein (according to D√ºtsch 18, footnote 57). Following this, statement and detailed proof appeared in (Brunetti-Fredenhagen 99).

Proof

We will construct an open cover of Œ£ n+1‚àñŒ£\Sigma^{n+1} \setminus \Sigma by subsets ùíû I‚äÇŒ£ n+1\mathcal{C}_I \subset \Sigma^{n+1} which are disjoint unions of non-empty sets that are in causal order, so that by causal factorization the time-ordered products T n+1T_{n+1} on these subsets are uniquely given by T k(‚àí)‚ãÜ HT n‚àík(‚àí)T_{k}(-) \star_H T_{n-k}(-). Then we show that these unique products on these special subsets do coincide on intersections. This yields the claim by a partition of unity.

We now say this in detail:

For I‚äÇ{1,‚ãØ,n+1}I \subset \{1, \cdots, n+1\} write I¬Ø‚âî{1,‚ãØ,n+1}‚àñI\overline{I} \coloneqq \{1, \cdots, n+1\} \setminus I. For I,I¬Ø‚â†‚àÖI, \overline{I} \neq \emptyset, define the subset

ùíû I‚âî{(x i) i‚àà{1,‚ãØ,n+1}‚ààŒ£ n+1|{x i} i‚ààI‚à®‚àß{x j} j‚àà{1,‚ãØ,n+1}‚àñI}‚äÇŒ£ n+1. \mathcal{C}_I \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ (x_i)_{i \in \{1, \cdots, n+1\}} \in \Sigma^{n+1} \;\vert\; \{x_i\}_{i \in I} {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \{x_j\}_{j \in \{1, \cdots, n+1\} \setminus I} \right\} \;\subset\; \Sigma^{n+1} \,.

Since the causal order-relation involves the closed future cones/closed past cones, respectively, it is clear that these are open subsets. Moreover it is immediate that they form an open cover of the complement of the diagonal:

‚à™I‚äÇ{1,‚ãØ,n+1}I,I¬Ø‚â†‚àÖùíû I=Œ£ n+1‚àñdiag(Œ£). \underset{ { I \subset \{1, \cdots, n+1\} \atop { I, \overline{I} \neq \emptyset } } }{\cup} \mathcal{C}_I \;=\; \Sigma^{n+1} \setminus diag(\Sigma) \,.

(Because any two distinct points in the globally hyperbolic spacetime Œ£\Sigma may be causally separated by a Cauchy surface, and any such may be deformed a little such as not to intersect any of a given finite set of points. )

Hence the condition of causal factorization on T n+1T_{n+1} implies that restricted to any ùíû I\mathcal{C}_{I} these have to be given (in the condensed generalized function-notation from remark 15 on any unordered tuple X={x 1,‚ãØ,x n+1}‚ààùíû I\mathbf{X} = \{x_1, \cdots, x_{n+1}\} \in \mathcal{C}_I with corresponding induced tuples I‚âî{x i} i‚ààI\mathbf{I} \coloneqq \{x_i\}_{i \in I} and I¬Ø‚âî{x i} i‚ààI¬Ø\overline{\mathbf{I}} \coloneqq \{x_i\}_{i \in \overline{I}} by

(15)T n+1(X)=T(I)T(I¬Ø)AAforAùí≥‚ààùíû I. T_{n+1}( \mathbf{X} ) \;=\; T(\mathbf{I}) T(\overline{\mathbf{I}}) \phantom{AA} \text{for} \phantom{A} \mathcal{X} \in \mathcal{C}_I \,.

This shows that T n+1T_{n+1} is unique on Œ£ n+1‚àñdiag(Œ£)\Sigma^{n+1} \setminus diag(\Sigma) if it exists at all, hence if these local identifications glue to a global definition of T n+1T_{n+1}. To see that this is the case, we have to consider any two such subsets

I 1,I 2‚äÇ{1,‚ãØ,n+1},AAI 1,I 2,I 1¬Ø,I 2¬Ø‚â†‚àÖ. I_1, I_2 \subset \{1, \cdots, n+1\} \,, \phantom{AA} I_1, I_2, \overline{I_1}, \overline{I_2} \neq \emptyset \,.

By definition this implies that for

X‚ààùíû I 1‚à©ùíû I 2 \mathbf{X} \in \mathcal{C}_{I_1} \cap \mathcal{C}_{I_2}

a tuple of spacetime points which decomposes into causal order with respect to both these subsets, the corresponding mixed intersections of tuples are spacelike separated:

I 1‚à©I 2¬Ø><I 1¬Ø‚à©I 2. \mathbf{I}_1 \cap \overline{\mathbf{I}_2} \; {\gt\!\!\!\!\lt} \; \overline{\mathbf{I}_1} \cap \mathbf{I}_2 \,.

By the assumption that the {T k} k‚â†n\{T_k\}_{k \neq n} satisfy causal factorization, this implies that the corresponding time-ordered products commute:

(16)T(I 1‚à©I 2¬Ø)T(I 1¬Ø‚à©I 2)=T(I 1¬Ø‚à©I 2)T(I 1‚à©I 2¬Ø). T(\mathbf{I}_1 \cap \overline{\mathbf{I}_2}) \, T(\overline{\mathbf{I}_1} \cap \mathbf{I}_2) \;=\; T(\overline{\mathbf{I}_1} \cap \mathbf{I}_2) \, T(\mathbf{I}_1 \cap \overline{\mathbf{I}_2}) \,.

Using this we find that the identifications of T n+1T_{n+1} on ùíû I 1\mathcal{C}_{I_1} and on ùíû I 2\mathcal{C}_{I_2}, accrding to (15), agree on the intersection: in that for X‚ààùíû I 1‚à©ùíû I 2 \mathbf{X} \in \mathcal{C}_{I_1} \cap \mathcal{C}_{I_2} we have

T(I 1)T(I 1¬Ø) =T(I 1‚à©I 2)T(I 1‚à©I 2¬Ø)T(I 1¬Ø‚à©I 2)T(I 1¬Ø‚à©I 2¬Ø) =T(I 1‚à©I 2)T(I 1¬Ø‚à©I 2)T(I 1‚à©I 2¬Ø)‚èüT(I 1¬Ø‚à©I 2¬Ø) =T(I 2)T(I 2¬Ø) \begin{aligned} T( \mathbf{I}_1 ) T( \overline{\mathbf{I}_1} ) & = T( \mathbf{I}_1 \cap \mathbf{I}_2 ) T( \mathbf{I}_1 \cap \overline{\mathbf{I}_2} ) \, T( \overline{\mathbf{I}_1} \cap \mathbf{I}_2 ) T( \overline{\mathbf{I}_1} \cap \overline{\mathbf{I}_2} ) \\ & = T( \mathbf{I}_1 \cap \mathbf{I}_2 ) \underbrace{ T( \overline{\mathbf{I}_1} \cap \mathbf{I}_2 ) T( \mathbf{I}_1 \cap \overline{\mathbf{I}_2} ) } T( \overline{\mathbf{I}_1} \cap \overline{\mathbf{I}_2} ) \\ & = T( \mathbf{I}_2 ) T( \overline{\mathbf{I}_2} ) \end{aligned}

Here in the first step we expanded out the two factors using (15) for I 2I_2, then under the brace we used (16) and in the last step we used again (15), but now for I 1I_1.

To conclude, let

(œá I‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£ n+1)) I‚äÇ{1,‚ãØ,n+1}I,I¬Ø‚â†‚àÖ \left( \chi_I \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma^{n+1}) \right)_{ { I \subset \{1, \cdots, n+1\} } \atop { I, \overline{I} \neq \emptyset } }

be a partition of unity subordinate to the open cover formed by the ùíû I\mathcal{C}_I. Then the above implies that setting for any X‚ààŒ£ n+1‚àñdiag(Œ£)\mathbf{X} \in \Sigma^{n+1} \setminus diag(\Sigma)

T n+1(X)‚âî‚àëI‚àà{1,‚ãØ,n+1}I,I¬Ø‚â†‚àÖœá i(X)T(I)T(I¬Ø) T_{n+1}(\mathbf{X}) \;\coloneqq\; \underset{ { I \in \{1, \cdots, n+1\} } \atop { I, \overline{I} \neq \emptyset } }{\sum} \chi_i(\mathbf{X}) T( \mathbf{I} ) T( \overline{\mathbf{I}} )

is well defined and satisfies causal factorization.

Since ("re"-)normalization involves making choices, there is the freedom to impose further conditions that one may want to have satisfied. These are called renormalization conditions.

Definition

(renormalization conditions and quantum anomalies)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

Then a condition PP on kk-ary functions of the form

T k:(LocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]) ‚äó ‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]] k‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg((‚Ñè))[[g,j]] T_k \;\colon\; \left( {\, \atop \,} LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [\hbar, g, j] ] {\, \atop \,} \right)^{\otimes^k_{\mathbb{C}[ [\hbar, g, j] ]}} \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}((\hbar))[ [g , j] ]

is called a renormalization condition if

  1. it holds for the unique time-ordered products away from coinciding spacetime arguments (according to prop. 10);

  2. whenever it holds for all unrestricted T k‚â§nT_{k \leq n} for some n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, then it also holds for T n+1T_{n+1} restricted away from the diagonal:

    P(T k) k‚â§n‚áíP(T n+1| Œ£ n+1‚àñdiag(Œ£)). P(T_k)_{k \leq n} \;\Rightarrow\; P\left( T_{n+1}\vert_{\Sigma^{n+1} \setminus diag(\Sigma)} \right) \,.

This means that a renormalization condition is a condition that may consistently be imposed degreewise in an inductive construction of time-ordered products by degreewise extension to the diagonal, according to prop. 11.

If for specified renormalization conditions {P i}\{P_i\} there is no choice of time-ordered products {T k} k‚àà‚Ñï\{T_k\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}} (def. 10) that satisfies all these conditions, then one says that an interacting perturbative QFT satisfying {P i}\{P_i\} fails to exist due to a quantum anomaly.

Proposition

(basic renormalization conditions)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

Then the following conditions are renormalization conditions (def. 17):

  1. (field independence) The functional derivative of a polynomial observable arising as a time-ordered product takes contributions only from the arguments, not from the product operation itself: In generalized function-notation:

    Œ¥Œ¥Œ¶ a(x)T(A 1,‚ãØ,A n)=‚àë1‚â§k‚â§nT(A 1,‚ãØ,A k‚àí1,Œ¥Œ¥Œ¶ a(x)A k,A k+1,‚ãØ,A n) \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}^a(x)} T(A_1, \cdots, A_n) \;=\; \underset{1 \leq k \leq n}{\sum} T\left( A_1, \cdots, A_{k-1}, \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}^a(x)}A_k, A_{k+1}, \cdots, A_n \right)

  2. (translation equivariance) If the underlying spacetime is Minkowski spacetime, Œ£=‚Ñù p,1\Sigma = \mathbb{R}^{p,1}, with the induced action of the translation group on polynomial observables

    œÅ:‚Ñù p,1√óPolyObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]] \rho \;\colon\; \mathbb{R}^{p,1} \times PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, j ] ] \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, j ] ]

    then

    œÅ v(T(A 1,‚ãØ,A n))=T(œÅ v(A 1),‚ãØ,œÅ v(A n)) \rho_v \left( {\, \atop \,} T(A_1, \cdots, A_n) {\, \atop \,}\right) \;=\; T(\rho_{v}(A_1), \cdots, \rho_v(A_n))

  3. (quantum master equation, master Ward identity) see prop. 17

    (if this condition fails, the corresponding quantum anomaly (def. 17) is called a gauge anomaly)

(Duetsch 18, p. 150 and section 4.2)

Proof

For the first two statements this is obvious from prop. 11 and prop. 10, which imply that T n+1| Œ£ n+1‚àñdiag(Œ£)T_{n+1}\vert_{\Sigma^{n+1} \setminus diag(\Sigma)} is uniquely specified from {T k} k‚â§n\{T_k\}_{k \leq n} via the star product induced by the Feynman propagator, and the fact that, on Minkowski spacetime, this is manifestly translation invariant and independent of the fields (e.q. prop. \ref{FeynmanPropagatorAsACauchyPrincipalvalue}).

The third statement requires work. That the quantum master equation/(master Ward identity always holds on regular polynomial observables is prop. 17 below. That it holds for T n+1| Œ£ n+1‚àñdiag(Œ£)T_{n+1}\vert_{\Sigma^{n+1} \setminus diag(\Sigma)} if it holds for {T k} k‚â§n\{T_k\}_{k \leq n} is shown in (Duetsch 18, section 4.2.2).

Theorem

(main theorem of perturbative renormalization)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

  1. An S-matrix renormalization scheme (def. 3) around this free vacuum, satisfying the renormalization conditions (def. 17) ‚Äúfield independence‚Äù and ‚Äútranslation inavriance‚Äù (prop. 12), exists, and its construction by choices of ("re"-)normalization of time-ordered products {T k} k‚àà‚Ñï\{T_k\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}} according to def. 16 involves precisely a finite-dimensional vector space of choices (‚Äúrenormalization constants‚Äù) at each order k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N}.

  2. Every pair ùíÆ\mathcal{S}, ùíÆÀú\widetilde{\mathcal{S}} of such choices are related by a unique transformation of the space of local observables (‚Äúadding counterterms to interactions‚Äù)

    Z:LocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g]]‚ü∂LocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,h]] Z \;\colon\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g ] ] \longrightarrow LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, h ] ]

    via precomposition

    ùíÆÀú=ùíÆ‚àòZ. \widetilde{\mathcal{S}} \;=\; \mathcal{S} \circ Z \,.

  3. The group of transformations ZZ arising this way is the St√ºckelberg-Petermann renormalization group.

In summary this says that for each free field vacuum, the space of renormalization schemes for perturbative QFT around this vacuum is non-empty and is canonically a torsor over the St√ºckelberg-Petermann renormalization group.

Notice that the St√ºckelberg-Petermann renormalization group involves neither scaling transformations as in Gell-Mann-Low renormalization cocycles, nor cutoffs as in Wilsonian effective field theory. But these alternative perspectives may be extracted as specia cases (Brunetti-D√ºtsch-Fredenhagen 09).

\,

Feynman perturbation series

By def 16 and the main theorem of perturbative renormalization (theorem 1), the construction of perturbative S-matrix schemes/time-ordered products may be phrased as ("re-")normalization of the star product induced by the Feynman propagator, namely as a choice of extension of distributions of the this star-product to the locus of coinciding interaction points.

Since the star product is the exponential of the binary contraction with the Feynman propagator, it is naturally expanded as a sum of products of distributions labeled by finite multigraphs (def. 18 below), where each vertex corresponds to an interaction or source field insertion, and where each edge corresponds to one contractions of two of these with the Feynman propagator. The products of distributions arising this way are the Feynman amplitudes (prop. 13 below).

If the free field vacuum is decomposed as a direct sum of distinct free field types/species (def. 19 below), then in addition to the vertices also the edges in these graphs receive labels, now by the field species whose particular Feynman propagator is being used in the contraction at that edges. These labeled graphs are now called Feynman diagrams (def. 20 below) and the products of distributions which they encode are their Feynman amplitudes built by the Feynman rules (prop. 14 below).

The choice of ("re"-)normalization of the time-ordered products/S-matrix is thus equivalently a choice of ("re"-)normalization of the Feynman amplitudes for all possible Feynman diagrams. These are usefully organized in powers of ‚Ñè\hbar by their loop order (prop. 16 below).

In conclusion, the Feynman rules make the perturbative S-matrix be equal to a formal power series of Feynman amplitudes labeled by Feynman graphs. As such it is known as the Feynman perturbation series (example 6 below).

Notice how it is therefore the combinatorics of star products that governs both Wick's lemma in free field theory as well as Feynman diagrammatics in interacting field theory:

\,

We now discuss Feynman diagrams and their Feynman amplitudes in two stages: First we consider plain finite multigraphs with linearly ordered vertices but no other labels (def. 18 below) and discuss how these generally organize an expansion of the time-ordered products as a sum of distributional products of the given Feynman propagator (prop. 13 below). These summands (or their vacuum expectation values) are called the Feynman amplitudes if one thinks of the underlying free field vacuum as having a single ‚Äúfield species‚Äù and of the chosen interaction to be a single ‚Äúinteraction vertex‚Äù.

But often it is possible and useful to identify different field species and different interaction vertices. In fact in applications this choice is typically evident and not highlighted as a choice. We make it explicit below as def. 19. Such a choice makes both the interaction term as well as the Feynman propagator decompose as sums (remark 16 below). Accordingly then, after ‚Äúmultiplying out‚Äù the products of these sums that appear in the Feynman amplitudes, these, too, decompose further as as sums indexed by multigraphs whose edges are labeled by field species, and whose vertices are labeled by interactions. These labeled multigraphs are the Feynman diagrams (def. 20 below) and the corresponding summands are the Feynman amplitudes proper (prop. 14 below).

Definition

(finite multigraphs)

A finite multigraph is

  1. a finite set VV (‚Äúof vertices‚Äù);

  2. a finite set EE (‚Äúof edges‚Äù);

  3. a function E‚Üíp{{v 1,v 2}={v 2,v 1}|v 1,v 2‚ààV,v 1‚â†v 2}E \overset{p}{\to} \left\{ {\,\atop \,} \{v_1, v_2\} = \{v_2, v_1\} \;\vert\; v_1, v_2 \in V \,,\; v_1 \neq v_2 {\, \atop \,} \right\}

    (sending any edge to the unordered pair of distinct vertices that it goes between).

A choice of linear order on the set of vertices of a finite multigraph is a choice of bijection of the form

V‚âÉ{1,2,‚ãØ,ŒΩ}. V \simeq \{1, 2, \cdots, \nu\} \,.

Hence the isomorphism classes of a finite multigraphs with linearly ordered vertices are characterized by

  1. a natural number

    ŒΩ‚âî|V|‚àà‚Ñï \nu \coloneqq {\vert V\vert} \in \mathbb{N}

    (the number of vertices);

  2. for each i<j‚àà{1,‚ãØ,ŒΩ}i \lt j \in \{1, \cdots, \nu\} a natural number

    e i,j‚âî|p ‚àí1({v i,v j})|‚àà‚Ñï e_{i,j} \coloneqq {\vert p^{-1}(\{v_i,v_j\})\vert} \in \mathbb{N}

    (the number of edges between the iith and the jjth vertex).

We write ùí¢ ŒΩ\mathcal{G}_\nu for the set of such isomorphism classes of finite multigraphs with linearly ordered vertices identified with {1,2,‚ãØ,ŒΩ}\{1, 2, \cdots, \nu\}; and we write

ùí¢‚âî‚äîŒΩ‚àà‚Ñïùí¢ ŒΩ \mathcal{G} \;\coloneqq\; \underset{\nu \in \mathbb{N}}{\sqcup} \mathcal{G}_\nu

for the set of isomorphism classes of finite multigraphs with linearly ordered vertices of any number.

Proposition

(Feynman amplitudes of finite multigraphs)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

For ŒΩ‚àà‚Ñï\nu \in \mathbb{N}, the ŒΩ\nu-fold time-ordered product away from coinciding interaction points, given by prop. 10

T ŒΩ:(LocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]) pds ‚äó ‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]] ŒΩ‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg((‚Ñè))[[g,j]] T_\nu \;\colon\; \left( {\, \atop \,} LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [\hbar, g, j] ] {\, \atop \,} \right)^{\otimes^\nu_{\mathbb{C}[ [\hbar, g, j] ]}}_{pds} \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}((\hbar))[ [g , j] ]

is equal to the following formal power series labeled by isomorphism classes of finite multigraphs with ŒΩ\nu linearly ordered vertices, Œì‚ààùí¢ ŒΩ\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}_\nu (def. 18):

Here the summands of the expansion (17)

and/or their vacuum expectation values

‚ü®Œì((V i) i=1 v)‚ü©‚àà‚ÑÇ((‚Ñè))[[h,j]] \left\langle \Gamma\left((V_i)_{i = 1}^v\right) \right\rangle \;\in\; \mathbb{C}((\hbar))[ [ h, j] ]

are called the Feynman amplitudes for scattering processes in the given free field vacuum of shape Œì\Gamma with interaction vertices O iO_i. Their expression as products of distributions via algebraic expression on the right hand side of (18) is also called the Feynman rules.

(Keller 10, IV.1)

Proof

We proceed by induction over the number vv of vertices. The statement is trivially true for a single vertex. So assume that it is true for v‚â•1v \geq 1 vertices. It follows that

T(O 1,‚ãØ,O ŒΩ,O ŒΩ+1) =T(T(O 1,‚ãØ,O ŒΩ),O ŒΩ+1) =prod‚àòexp(‚ü®‚ÑèŒî F,Œ¥Œ¥Œ¶‚äóŒ¥Œ¥Œ¶‚ü©)((prod‚àò‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢ ŒΩ‚àèr<s‚àà{1,‚ãØ,ŒΩ}1e r,s!‚ü®(‚ÑèŒî F) e r,s,Œ¥ e r,sŒ¥Œ¶ r e r,sŒ¥ e r,sŒ¥Œ¶ s e r,s‚ü©(O 1‚äó‚ãØ‚äóO ŒΩ))‚äóO ŒΩ+1) =prod‚àò‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢ ŒΩ =‚àèr<s‚àà{1,‚ãØ,ŒΩ}1e r,s!‚ü®(‚ÑèŒî F) e r,s,Œ¥ e r,sŒ¥Œ¶ r e r,sŒ¥ e r,sŒ¥Œ¶ s e r,s‚ü© =‚àëe ŒΩ+1=e 1,ŒΩ+1+‚ãØ+e ŒΩ,ŒΩ+1(e ŒΩ+1(e 1,ŒΩ+1),‚ãØ,(e ŒΩ,ŒΩ+1))(e ŒΩ+1)!‚èü=(e 1,ŒΩ+1)‚ãØ(e ŒΩ,ŒΩ+1))‚ü®(‚ÑèŒî F) e ŒΩ+1(Œ¥ e 1,ŒΩ+1O 1Œ¥Œ¶ e 1,ŒΩ+1‚äó‚ãØ‚äóŒ¥ e ŒΩ,ŒΩ+1O ŒΩŒ¥Œ¶ e ŒΩ,ŒΩ+1‚äóŒ¥ e ŒΩ+1O ŒΩ+1Œ¥Œ¶ e 1,ŒΩ+1+‚ãØ+e ŒΩ,ŒΩ+1‚ü©) =prod‚àò‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢ ŒΩ+1‚àèr<s‚àà{1,‚ãØ,ŒΩ+1}1e r,s!‚ü®(‚ÑèŒî F) e r,s,Œ¥ e r,sŒ¥Œ¶ r e r,sŒ¥ e r,sŒ¥Œ¶ s e r,s‚ü©(O 1‚äó‚ãØ‚äóO ŒΩ+1) \begin{aligned} & T(O_1, \cdots, O_\nu, O_{\nu+1}) \\ & = T( T(O_1, \cdots ,O_\nu), O_{\nu+1} ) \\ &= prod \circ \exp\left( \left\langle \hbar \Delta_F, \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}} \otimes \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}} \right\rangle \right) \left( \left( prod \circ \!\!\!\! \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}_\nu }{\sum} \underset{ { r \lt s } \atop { \in \{1, \cdots, \nu\} } }{\prod} \frac{1}{e_{r,s}!} \left\langle (\hbar \Delta_F)^{e_{r,s}} \,,\, \frac{\delta^{e_{r,s}}}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}_r^{e_{r,s}}} \frac{\delta^{e_{r,s}}}{ \delta \mathbf{\Phi}_s^{e_{r,s}} } \right\rangle (O_1 \otimes \cdots \otimes O_\nu) \right) \,\otimes\, O_{\nu+1} \right) \\ & = prod \circ \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}_\nu }{\sum} \\ & \phantom{=} \underset{ { r \lt s } \atop { \in \{1,\cdots, \nu\}} }{\prod} \frac{1}{e_{r,s}!} \left\langle (\hbar \Delta_F)^{e_{r,s}} \,,\, \frac{\delta^{e_{r,s}}}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}_r^{e_{r,s}}} \frac{\delta^{e_{r,s}}}{ \delta \mathbf{\Phi}_s^{e_{r,s}} } \right\rangle \\ & \phantom{=} \underset{ { e_{\nu+1} =} \atop { e_{1,{\nu+1}} + \cdots + e_{\nu,\nu + 1} } }{\sum} \underset{ = (e_{1,\nu + 1}) \cdots (e_{\nu,\nu+1})) }{ \underbrace{ \frac{ \left( { e_{\nu + 1} } \atop { (e_{1, \nu + 1}), \cdots, (e_{\nu , \nu+1}) } \right) }{ ( e_{\nu+1} ) ! } } } \left\langle (\hbar \Delta_F)^{e_{\nu+1}} \left( \frac{\delta^{e_{1,\nu+1}} O_1 }{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}^{e_{1,\nu+1}}} \otimes \cdots \otimes \frac{ \delta^{e_{\nu,\nu+1}} O_\nu }{ \delta \mathbf{\Phi}^{e_{\nu,\nu+1}} } \;\otimes\; \frac{ \delta^{ e_{\nu + 1} } O_{\nu+1} }{ \delta \mathbf{\Phi}^{e_{1,\nu+1} + \cdots + e_{\nu,\nu+1}} } \right\rangle \right) \\ &= prod \circ \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}_{\nu+1} }{\sum} \underset{ { r \lt s } \atop { \in \{1, \cdots, \nu+1\} } }{\prod} \tfrac{1}{e_{r,s}!} \left\langle (\hbar \Delta_F)^{e_{r,s}} \,,\, \frac{\delta^{e_{r,s}}}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}_r^{e_{r,s}}} \frac{\delta^{e_{r,s}}}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}_s^{e_{r,s}}} \right\rangle (O_1 \otimes \cdots \otimes O_{\nu+1}) \end{aligned}

The combinatorial factor over the brace is the multinomial coefficient expressing the number of ways of distributing e ŒΩ+1e_{\nu+1}-many functional derivatives to vv factors, via the product rule, and quotiented by the factorial that comes from the exponential in the definition of the star product.

Here in the first step we used the associativity (14) of the restricted time-ordered product, in the second step we used the induction assumption, in the third we passed the outer functional derivatives through the pointwise product using the product rule, and in the fourth step we recognized that this amounts to summing in addition over all possible choices of sets of edges from the first vv vertices to the new ŒΩ+1\nu+1st vertex, which yield in total the sum over all diagrams with ŒΩ+1\nu+1 vertices.

If the free field theory is decomposed as a direct sum of free field theories, we obtain a more fine-grained concept of Feynman amplitudes:

Definition

(field species and interaction vertices)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, and let gS int+jA‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚ü®g,j‚ü©g S_{int} + j A \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar , g , j] ]\langle g,j \rangle be a local observable regarded as an adiabatically switched interaction action functional.

Then

  1. a choice of field species is a choice of decomposition of the BV-BRST field bundle E BV-BRSTE_{\text{BV-BRST}} as a fiber product over finite set Spec={sp 1,sp 2,‚ãØ,sp n}Spec = \{sp_1, sp_2, \cdots, sp_n\} of (graded super-) field bundles

    E BV-BRST‚âÉE sp 1√ó Œ£‚ãØ√ó Œ£E sp n, E_{\text{BV-BRST}} \;\simeq\; E_{sp_1} \times_{\Sigma} \cdots \times_\Sigma E_{sp_n} \,,

    such that the gauge fixed free Lagrangian density L‚Ä≤\mathbf{L}' is the sum

    L‚Ä≤=L‚Ä≤ sp 1+‚ãØ+L‚Ä≤ sp n \mathbf{L}' \;=\; \mathbf{L}'_{sp_1} + \cdots + \mathbf{L}'_{sp_n}

    of free Lagrangian densities

    L‚Ä≤ sp i‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E i) \mathbf{L}'_{sp_i} \in \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E_i)

on these separate field bundles.

  1. a choice of interaction vertices and external vertices is a choice of sum decomposition

    gS int+jA=‚àëi‚ààExtgS int,i+‚àëj‚ààIntjA j g S_{int} + j A \;=\; \underset{i \in Ext}{\sum} g S_{int,i} + \underset{j \in Int}{\sum} j A_j

    parameterized by finite sets IntInt and ExtExt, to be called the sets of internal vertex labels and external vertex labels, respectively.

Remark

(Feynman propagator for separate field species)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1.

Then a choice of field species as in def. 19 induces a corresponding decomposition of the Feynman propagator of the gauge fixed free field theory

Œî F‚ààŒì‚Ä≤ Œ£√óŒ£(E BV-BRST‚ä†E BV-BRST) \Delta_F \;\in\; \Gamma'_{\Sigma \times \Sigma}( E_{\text{BV-BRST}} \boxtimes E_{\text{BV-BRST}} )

as the sum of Feynman propagators for each of the chosen field species:

Œî F=Œî F,1+‚ãØ+Œî F,n‚àà‚äïi=1nŒì‚Ä≤ Œ£√óŒ£(E sp i‚ä†E sp i)‚äÇŒì‚Ä≤ Œ£√óŒ£(E BV-BRST‚ä†E BV-BRST) \Delta_F \;=\; \Delta_{F,1} + \cdots + \Delta_{F,n} \;\in\; \underoverset{i = 1}{n}{\oplus} \Gamma'_{\Sigma \times \Sigma}( E_{sp_i} \boxtimes E_{sp_i} ) \;\subset\; \Gamma'_{\Sigma \times \Sigma}( E_{\text{BV-BRST}} \boxtimes E_{\text{BV-BRST}} )

hence in components, with (œï A(\phi^A the collective field coordinates on E BV-BRSTE_{\text{BV-BRST}}, this decomposition is of the form

(Œî F A,B)=((Œî F,1 ab) 0 0 ‚ãØ 0 0 (Œî F,2 Œ±Œ≤) 0 ‚ãØ 0 ‚ãÆ ‚ãÆ 0 ‚ãØ ‚ãØ 0 (Œî F,n ij)) \left( \Delta_F^{A, B} \right) \;=\; \left( \array{ (\Delta_{F,1}^{a b}) & 0 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & (\Delta_{F,2}^{\alpha \beta}) & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ \vdots & & & & \vdots \\ 0 & \cdots & \cdots & 0 & (\Delta_{F,n}^{i j}) } \right)
