Example

(field species in quantum electrodynamics)

The field bundle for Lorenz gauge fixed quantum electrodynamics on Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma admits a decomposition into field species, according to def. 19, as

E BV-BRST=(S odd√óŒ£)‚èüDiracfield√ó Œ£T *Œ£√ó Œ£(‚Ñù√óŒ£)‚èüelectromagnetic field &Nakanishi-Lautrup field√ó Œ£(‚Ñù[1]√óŒ£)‚èüghost field√ó Œ£(‚Ñù[‚àí1]√óŒ£)‚èüantighost field E_{\text{BV-BRST}} \;=\; \underset{ \text{Dirac} \atop \text{field} }{ \underbrace{ (S_{odd} \times \Sigma) }} \times_\Sigma \underset{ {\text{electromagnetic field &amp;}} \atop {\text{Nakanishi-Lautrup field}} }{ \underbrace{ T^\ast\Sigma \times_\Sigma (\mathbb{R} \times \Sigma) }} \times_\Sigma \underset{ \text{ghost field} }{ \underbrace{ (\mathbb{R}[1] \times \Sigma) } } \times_\Sigma \underset{ \text{antighost field} }{ \underbrace{ (\mathbb{R}[-1] \times \Sigma) } }

(by example \ref{LagrangianQED}) and example \ref{NLGaugeFixingOfElectromagnetism})).

The corresponding sum decomposition of the Feynman propagator, according to remark 16, is

Œî F=Œî F electron‚èüDiracfield+(Œî F photon * * *)‚èüelectromagnetic field &Nakanishi-Lautrup field+Œî F ghost+Œî F antighost, \Delta_F \;=\; \underset{ \text{Dirac} \atop \text{field} }{ \underbrace{ \Delta_F^{\text{electron}} } } + \underset{ \text{electromagnetic field &amp;} \atop \text{Nakanishi-Lautrup field} }{ \underbrace{ \left( \array{ \Delta_F^{photon} & * \\ * & * } \right) } } + \Delta_F^{ghost} + \Delta_F^{\text{antighost}} \,,

where

  1. Œî F electron\Delta_F^{\text{electron}} is the electron propagator (def. \ref{FeynmanPropagatorForDiracOperatorOnMinkowskiSpacetim}))

  2. Œî F photon\Delta_F^{photon} is the photon propagator in Gaussian-averaged Lorenz gauge (prop. \ref{PhotonPropagatorInGaussianAveragedLorenzGauge})

  3. the auxiliary field Feynman propagators Œî F ghost\Delta_F^{ghost}, Œî F NL\Delta_F^{NL} and Œî F antighost\Delta_F^{antighost} are each one copy of the Feynman propagator of the real scalar field (prop. \ref{FeynmanPropagatorAsACauchyPrincipalvalue}).

Definition

(Feynman diagrams)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, and let gS int+jA‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚ü®g,j‚ü©g S_{int} + j A \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar , g , j] ]\langle g,j \rangle be a local observable regarded as an adiabatically switched interaction action functional.

Let moreover

E BV-BRST‚âÉ√ósp‚ààSpecE sp, E_{\text{BV-BRST}} \;\simeq\; \underset{sp \in Spec}{\times} E_{sp} \,,

be a choice of field species, according to def 19,

gS int+jA=‚àëi‚ààExtgS int,i+Sumj‚ààIntjA j g S_{int} + j A \;=\; \underset{i \in Ext}{\sum} g S_{int,i} + \underset{j \in Int}{\Sum} j A_j

a choice of internal and external interaction vertices according to def. 19.

With these choices, we say that a Feynman diagram (Œì,vertlab,edgelab)(\Gamma, vertlab, edgelab) is

  1. a finite multigraph with linearly ordered vertices (def. 18)

    Œì‚ààùí¢, \Gamma \in \mathcal{G} \,,

  2. a function from its vertices

    vertlab:V Œì‚ü∂Int‚äîExt vertlab \;\colon\; V_{\Gamma} \longrightarrow Int \sqcup Ext

    to the disjoint union of the chosen sets of internal and external vertex labels;

  3. a function from its edges

    edgelab:E Œì‚ÜíSpec edgelab \;\colon\; E_{\Gamma} \to Spec

    to the chosen set of field species.

We write

ùí¢ Feyn ‚ü∂forgetlabels ùí¢ (Œì,vertlab,edgelab) ‚Ü¶ Œì \array{ \mathcal{G}^{Feyn} &\overset{\text{forget} \atop \text{labels}}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{G} \\ (\Gamma,vertlab, edgelab) &\mapsto& \Gamma }

for the set of isomorphism classes of Feynman diagrams with labels in SpSp, refining the set of isomorphisms of plain finite multigraphs with linearly ordered vertices from def. 18.

Proposition

(Feynman amplitudes for Feynman diagrams)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, and let gS int+jA‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚ü®g,j‚ü©g S_{int} + j A \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar , g , j] ]\langle g,j \rangle be a local observable regarded as an adiabatically switched interaction action functional.

Let moreover

E BV-BRST‚âÉ√ósp‚ààSpecE sp, E_{\text{BV-BRST}} \;\simeq\; \underset{sp \in Spec}{\times} E_{sp} \,,

be a choice of field species, according to def 19, hence inducing, by remark 16, a sum decomposition of the Feynman propagator

(19)Œî F=‚àësp‚ààSpecŒî F,sp, \Delta_F \;=\; \underset{sp \in Spec}{\sum}\Delta_{F,sp} \,,

and let

(20)gS int+jA=‚àëi‚ààExtgS int,i+Sumj‚ààIntjA j g S_{int} + j A \;=\; \underset{i \in Ext}{\sum} g S_{int,i} + \underset{j \in Int}{\Sum} j A_j

be a choice of internal and external interaction vertices according to def. 19.

Then by ‚Äúmultiplying out‚Äù the products of the sums (19) and (20) in the formula (18) for the Feynman amplitude Œì((gS int+jA)) i=1 ŒΩ)\Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A))_{i = 1}^\nu \right) (def. 13) this decomposes as a sum of the form

Œì((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ)=‚àëV Œì‚ü∂vertlabInt‚äîExtE Œì‚ü∂edgelabSpec(Œì,edgelab,vertlab)(gS int+jA) \Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^\nu \right) \;=\; \underset{ { V_\Gamma \overset{vertlab}{\longrightarrow} Int \sqcup Ext} \atop { E_\Gamma \overset{edgelab}{\longrightarrow} Spec } }{\sum} \left( \Gamma, edgelab, vertlab \right) (g S_{int} + j A)

over all ways of labeling the vertices vv of Œì\Gamma by the internal or external vertex labels, and the edges ee of Œì\Gamma by field species. The corresponding summands

(Œì,edgelab,vertlab)(gS int+jA)‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]] \left( \Gamma, edgelab, vertlab \right) (g S_{int} + j A) \;\in\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, j] ]

or rather their vacuum expectation value

‚ü®(Œì,edgelab,vertlab)(gS int+jA)‚ü©‚àà‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]] \left\langle \left( \Gamma, edgelab, vertlab \right) (g S_{int} + j A) \right\rangle \;\in\; \mathbb{C}[ [ \hbar, g, j ] ]

are called the Feynman amplitude associated with these Feynman diagrams.

Example

(Feynman amplitudes in causal perturbation theory ‚Äì example of QED)

In perturbative quantum field theory, Feynman diagrams are labeled multigraphs that encode products of Feynman propagators, called Feynman amplitudes (this prop.) which in turn contribute to probability amplitudes for physical scattering processes:

The Feynman amplitudes are the summands in the Feynman perturbation series-expansion of the scattering matrix

ùíÆ(S int)=‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï1k!1(i‚Ñè) kT(S int,‚ãØ,S int‚èükfactors) \mathcal{S} \left( S_{int} \right) = \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \frac{1}{k!} \frac{1}{(i \hbar)^k} T( \underset{k \, \text{factors}}{\underbrace{S_{int}, \cdots , S_{int}}} )

of a given interaction Lagrangian density L intL_{int}.

The Feynman amplitudes are the summands in an expansion of the time-ordered products T(‚ãØ)T(\cdots) of the interaction with itself, which, away from coincident vertices, is given by the star product of the Feynman propagator Œî F\Delta_F (this prop.), via the exponential contraction

T(S int,S int)=prod‚àòexp(‚Ñè‚à´Œî F ab(x,y)Œ¥Œ¥Œ¶ a(x)‚äóŒ¥Œ¥Œ¶(y))(S int‚äóS int). T(S_{int}, S_{int}) \;=\; prod \circ \exp \left( \hbar \int \Delta_{F}^{a b}(x,y) \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}^a(x)} \otimes \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}(y)} \right) ( S_{int} \otimes S_{int} ) \,.

Each edge in a Feynman diagram corresponds to a factor of a Feynman propagator in T(S int‚ãØS int‚èükfactors)T( \underset{k \, \text{factors}}{\underbrace{S_{int} \cdots S_{int}}} ), being a distribution of two variables; and each vertex corresponds to a factor of the interaction Lagrangian density at x ix_i.

For example quantum electrodynamics in Gaussian-averaged Lorenz gauge involves (via this example):

  1. the Dirac field modelling the electron, with Feynman propagator called the electron propagator (this def.), here to be denoted

    ŒîAAAAelectron propagator \Delta \phantom{AAAA} \text{electron propagator}

  2. the electromagnetic field modelling the photon, with Feynman propagator called the photon propagator (this prop.), here to be denoted

    GAAAAphoton propagator G \phantom{AAAA} \text{photon propagator}

  3. the electron-photon interaction

    L int=ig(Œ≥ Œº) Œ± Œ≤‚èüinteractionœà Œ±¬Ø‚èüincomingelectronfielda Œº‚èüphotonfieldœà Œ≤‚èüoutgoingelectronfield L_{int} \;=\; \underset{ \text{interaction} }{ \underbrace{ i g (\gamma^\mu)^\alpha{}_\beta } } \, \underset{ { \text{incoming} \atop \text{electron} } \atop \text{field} }{\underbrace{\overline{\psi_\alpha}}} \; \underset{ { \, \atop \text{photon} } \atop \text{field} }{\underbrace{a_\mu}} \; \underset{ {\text{outgoing} \atop \text{electron} } \atop \text{field} }{\underbrace{\psi^\beta}}

The Feynman diagram for the electron-photon interaction alone is

where the solid lines correspond to the electron, and the wiggly line to the photon. The corresponding product of distributions is (written in generalized function-notation)

‚Ñè 3/2‚àí1‚èüloop orderig(Œ≥ Œº) Œ± Œ≤‚èüelectron-photoninteraction.Œî(‚àí,x)¬Ø ‚àí,Œ±‚èüincomingelectronpropagatorG(x,‚àí) Œº,‚àí‚èüphotonpropagatorŒî(x,‚àí) Œ≤,‚àí‚èüoutgoingelectronpropagator \underset{ \text{loop order} }{ \underbrace{ \hbar^{3/2-1} } } \underset{ \text{electron-photon} \atop \text{interaction} }{ \underbrace{ i g (\gamma^\mu)^\alpha{}_\beta } } \,. \, \underset{ {\text{incoming} \atop \text{electron}} \atop \text{propagator} }{ \underbrace{ \overline{\Delta(-,x)}_{-, \alpha} } } \underset{ { \, \atop \text{photon} } \atop \text{propagator} }{ \underbrace{ G(x,-)_{\mu,-} } } \underset{ { \text{outgoing} \atop \text{electron} } \atop \text{propagator} }{ \underbrace{ \Delta(x,-)^{\beta, -} } }

Hence a typical Feynman diagram in the QED Feynman perturbation series induced by this electron-photon interaction looks as follows:

For instance the two solid edges between the vertices x 2x_2 and x 3x_3 correspond to the two factors of Œî(x 2,x 2)\Delta(x_2,x_2):

A priori this product of distributions is defined away from coincident vertices: x i‚â†x jx_i \neq x_j. The definition at coincident vertices x i=x jx_i = x_j requires a choice of extension of distributions to the diagonal locus. This choice is the ("re-")normalization of the Feynman amplitude.

Example

(Feynman perturbation series)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, and let

gS int+jA‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,h]]‚ü®g,j‚ü© g S_{int} + j A \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, h ] ]\langle g , j\rangle

be a local observable, regarded as a adiabatically switched interaction action functional.

By prop. 13 every choice of perturbative S-matrix (def. 3)

ùíÆ(gS int+jA)‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST) mc((‚Ñè))[[g,j]]+ \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) \;\in\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{mc}((\hbar))[ [ g, j ] ] +

has an expansion as a formal power series of the form

ùíÆ(gS int+jA)=‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢Œì((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì)), \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) \;=\; \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}}{\sum} \Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma)}\right) \,,

where the series is over all finite multigraphs with linearly ordered vertices Œì\Gamma (def. 18), and the summands are the corresponding ("re"-)normalized (def. 16) Feynman amplitudes (prop. 13).

If moreover a choice of field species and of internal and external interaction vertices is made, according to def. 19, then this series expansion refines to an expansion over all Feynman diagrams (Œì,edgelab,vertlab)(\Gamma,edgelab, vertlab) (def. 20) of Feynman amplitudes (Œì,edgelab,vertlab)(gS int+jA)(\Gamma, edgelab,vertlab)(g S_{int} + j A) (def. 14):

ùíÆ(gS int+jA)=‚àë(Œì,edgelab,vertlab)‚ààùí¢ Feyn(Œì,edgelab,vertlab)(gS int+jA), \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) \;=\; \underset{(\Gamma,edgelab, vertlab) \in \mathcal{G}^{Feyn}}{\sum} (\Gamma, edgelab,vertlab)(g S_{int} + j A) \,,

Expressed in this form the S-matrix is known as the Feynman perturbation series.

Remark

(no tadpole Feynman diagrams)

In the definition of finite multigraphs in def. 18 there are no edges considered that go from any vertex to itself. Accordingly, there are no such labeled edges in Feynman diagrams (def. 20):

In pQFT these diagrams are called tadpoles, and their non-appearance is considered part of the Feynman rules (prop. 13). Via prop. 13 this condition reflects the nature of the star product (def. \ref{PropagatorStarProduct}) which always contracts different tensor product factors with the Feynman propagator before taking their pointwise product.

Beware that in graph theory these tadpoles are called ‚Äúloops‚Äù, while here in pQFT a ‚Äúloop‚Äù in a planar graph refers instead to what in graph theory is called a face of the graph, see the discussion of loop order in prop. 16 below.

(Keller 10, remark II.8 and proof of prop. II.7)

\,

Effective action

We have seen that the Feynman perturbation series expresses the S-matrix as a formal power series of Feynman amplitudes labeled by Feynman diagrams. Now the Feynman amplitude associated with a disjoint union of connected Feynman diagrams (def. 21 below) is just the product of the amplitudes of the connected components (prop. 15 below). This allows to re-organize the Feynman perturbation series as the ordinary exponential of the Feynman perturbation series restricted to just connected Feynman diagrams. The latter is called the effective action (def. 22 below) because it allows to express vacuum expectation values of the S-matrix as an ordinary exponential (equation (22) below).

Definition

(connected graphs)

Given two finite multigraphs Œì 1,Œì 2‚ààùí¢\Gamma_1, \Gamma_2 \in \mathcal{G} (def. 18), their disjoint union

Œì 1‚äîŒì 2‚ààùí¢ \Gamma_1 \sqcup \Gamma_2 \;\in\; \mathcal{G}

is the finite multigraph whose set of vertices and set of edges are the disjoint unions of the corresponding sets of Œì 1\Gamma_1 and Œì 2\Gamma_2

V Œì 1‚äîŒì 2‚âîV Œì 1‚äîV Œì 2 V_{\Gamma_1 \sqcup \Gamma_2} \;\coloneqq\; V_{\Gamma_1} \sqcup V_{\Gamma_2}
E Œì 1‚äîŒì 2‚âîE Œì 1‚äîE Œì 2 E_{\Gamma_1 \sqcup \Gamma_2} \;\coloneqq\; E_{\Gamma_1} \sqcup E_{\Gamma_2}

and whose vertex-assigning function pp is the corresponding function on disjoint unions

p Œì 1‚äîŒì 2‚âîp Œì 1‚äîp Œì 2. p_{\Gamma_1 \sqcup \Gamma_2} \;\coloneqq\; p_{\Gamma_1} \sqcup p_{\Gamma_2} \,.

The operation induces a pairing on the set ùí¢\mathcal{G} of isomorphism classes of finite multigraphs

(‚àí)‚äî(‚àí):ùí¢√óùí¢‚ü∂ùí¢. (-) \sqcup (-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{G} \times \mathcal{G} \longrightarrow \mathcal{G} \,.

A finite multigraph Œì‚ààùí¢\Gamma \in \mathcal{G} (def. 18) is called connected if it is not the disjoint union of two non-empty finite multigraphs.

We write

ùí¢ conn‚äÇùí¢ \mathcal{G}_{conn} \subset \mathcal{G}

for the subset of isomorphism classes of connected finite multigraphs.

Lemma

(Feynman amplitudes multiply under disjoint union of graphs)

Let

Œì=Œì 1‚äîŒì 2‚äî‚ãØ‚äîŒì n‚ààùí¢ \Gamma \;=\; \Gamma_1 \sqcup \Gamma_2 \sqcup \cdots \sqcup \Gamma_n \;\in\; \mathcal{G}

be disjoint union of graphs (def. 21). then then corresponding Feynman amplitudes (prop. 13) multiply by the pointwise product (def. \ref{Observable}):

Œì(gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì))=Œì 1((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì 1))‚ãÖŒì 2((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì 2))‚ãÖ‚ãØ‚ãÖŒì n((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì n)). \Gamma\left( g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma)} \right) \;=\; \Gamma_1\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma_1)}\right) \cdot \Gamma_2\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma_2)} \right) \cdot \cdots \cdot \Gamma_n\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma_n)} \right) \,.
Proof

By prop. 10 the contributions to the S-matrix away from coinciding interaction points are given by the star product induced by the Feynman propagator, and specifically, by prop. 13, the Feynman amplitudes are given this way. Moreover the star product (def. \ref{PropagatorStarProduct}) is given by first contracting with powers of the Feynman propagator and then multiplying all resulting terms with the pointwise product of observables. This implies the claim by the nature of the combinatorial factor in the definition of the Feynman amplitudes (prop. 13).

Definition

(effective action)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, let ùíÆ\mathcal{S} be an S-matrix scheme for perturbative QFT around this vacuum (def. 3) and let

gS int+jA‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,h]] g S_{int} + j A \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, h ] ]

be a local observable.

Recall that for each finite multigraph Œì‚ààùí¢\Gamma \in \mathcal{G} (def. 18) the Feynman perturbation series for ùíÆ(gS int+jA)\mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) (example 6)

ùíÆ(gS int+jA)=‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢Œì((gS int+jA) i=1 v(Œì)) \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) \;=\; \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}}{\sum} \Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{v(\Gamma)} \right)

contributes with a ("re"-)nromalized Feynman amplitude Œì((gS int+jA) i=1 v)‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST)((‚Ñè))[[g,j]]\Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^v\right) \in PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})((\hbar))[ [ g, j ] ].

We say that the corresponding effective action is i‚Ñèi \hbar times the sub-series

(21)S eff(g,j)‚âîi‚Ñè‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢ connŒì((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì))‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST)((‚Ñè))[[g,j]] S_{eff}(g,j) \;\coloneqq\; i \hbar \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}_{conn}}{\sum} \Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma)} \right) \;\in\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})((\hbar))[ [ g, j ] ]

of Feynman amplitudes that are labeled only by the connected graphs Œì‚ààùí¢ conn‚äÇùí¢\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}_{conn} \subset \mathcal{G} (def. 21).

The terminology ‚Äúeffective action‚Äù is due to the following fact:

Proposition

(effective action is logarithm of S-matrix)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, let ùíÆ\mathcal{S} be an S-matrix scheme for perturbative QFT around this vacuum (def. 3) and let

gS int+jA‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,h]] g S_{int} + j A \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, h ] ]

be a local observable and let

S eff(g,j)‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST)((‚Ñè))[[g,j]] S_{eff}(g,j) \;\in\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})((\hbar))[ [ g, j] ]

be the corresponding effective action (def. 22).

Then then S-matrix for gS int+jAg S_{int} + j A is the exponential of the effective action with respect to the pointwise product (‚àí)‚ãÖ(‚àí)(-)\cdot (-) of observables (def. \ref{Observable}):

ùíÆ(gS int+jA) =exp ‚ãÖ(1i‚ÑèS eff(g,j)) ‚âî1+1i‚ÑèS eff(g,j)+1(i‚Ñè) 2S eff(g,j)‚ãÖS eff(g,j)+1(i‚Ñè) 3S eff(g,j)‚ãÖS eff(g,j)‚ãÖS eff(g,j)+‚ãØ \begin{aligned} \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) & = \exp_\cdot\left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{eff}(g,j) \right) \\ & \coloneqq 1 + \frac{1}{i \hbar} S_{eff}(g,j) + \frac{1}{(i \hbar)^2} S_{eff}(g,j) \cdot S_{eff}(g,j) + \frac{1}{(i \hbar)^3} S_{eff}(g,j) \cdot S_{eff}(g,j) \cdot S_{eff}(g,j) + \cdots \end{aligned}

Moreover, this relation passes to the vacuum expectation values:

(22)‚ü®ùíÆ(gS int+jA)‚ü© =‚ü®exp(1i‚ÑèS eff(g,j))‚ü© =e 1i‚Ñè‚ü®S eff(g,j)‚ü©. \begin{aligned} \left\langle {\, \atop \,} \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) {\, \atop \,} \right\rangle & = \left\langle {\, \atop \,} \exp\left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{eff}(g,j) \right) {\, \atop \,} \right\rangle \\ & = e^{\tfrac{1}{i \hbar} \langle S_{eff}(g,j) \rangle} \end{aligned} \,.

Conversely the vacuum expectation value of the effective action is to the logarithm of that of the S-matrix:

‚ü®S eff(g,j)‚ü©=i‚Ñèln‚ü®ùíÆ(gS int+jA)‚ü©. \left\langle S_{eff}(g,j) \right\rangle \;=\; i \hbar \, \ln \left\langle \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) \right\rangle \,.
Proof

By lemma 1 the summands in the nnth pointwise power of 1i‚Ñè\frac{1}{i \hbar} times the effective action are precisely the Feynman amplitudes Œì((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì))\Gamma\left((g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma)}\right) of finite multigraphs Œì\Gamma with nn connected components, where each such appears with multiplicity given by the factorial of nn:

1n!(1i‚ÑèS eff(g,j)) n=‚àëŒì=‚äîj=1nŒì jŒì j‚ààùí¢ connŒì((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì)). \frac{1}{n!} \left( \frac{1}{i \hbar} S_{eff}(g,j) \right)^n \;=\; \underset{ { \Gamma = \underoverset{j = 1}{n}{\sqcup} \Gamma_j } \atop { \Gamma_j \in \mathcal{G}_{conn} } }{\sum} \Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma)} \right) \,.

It follows that

exp ‚ãÖ(1i‚ÑèS int) =‚àën‚àà‚Ñï‚àëŒì=‚äîj=1nŒì jŒì j‚ààùí¢ connŒì((gS int+jA) i=1 v(Œì)) =‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢Œì((gS int+jA) i=1 v(Œì)) \begin{aligned} \exp_\cdot\left( \frac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) & = \underset{n \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \underset{ { \Gamma = \underoverset{j = 1}{n}{\sqcup} \Gamma_j } \atop { \Gamma_j \in \mathcal{G}_{conn} } }{\sum} \Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{v(\Gamma)} \right) \\ & = \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}}{\sum} \Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{v(\Gamma)} \right) \end{aligned}

yields the Feynman perturbation series by expressing it as a series (re-)organized by number of connected components of the Feynman diagrams.

To conclude the proof it is now sufficient to observe that taking vacuum expectation values of polynomial observables respects the pointwise product of observables

‚ü®A 1‚ãÖA 2‚ü©=‚ü®A 1‚ü©‚ü®A 2‚ü©. \left\langle A_1 \cdot A_2 \right\rangle \;=\; \left\langle A_1 \right\rangle \, \left\langle A_2 \right\rangle \,.

This is because the Hadamard vacuum state ‚ü®‚àí‚ü©:PolyObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚Üí‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]]\langle -\rangle \colon PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, j] ] \to \mathbb{C}[ [\hbar, g, j ] ] simply picks the zero-order monomial term, by prop. \ref{WickAlgebraCanonicalState}), and under multiplication of polynomials the zero-order terms are multiplied.

The perspective of the effective action gives a transparent picture of the order of quantum effects involved in the S-matrix, this is prop. 16 below. In order to state this conveniently, we invoke two basic concepts from graph theory:

Definition

(planar graphs and trees)

A finite multigraph (def. 18) is called a planar graph if it admits an embedding into the plane, hence if it may be ‚Äúdrawn into the plane‚Äù without intersections, in the evident way.

A finite multigraph is called a tree if for any two of its vertices there is at most one path of edges connecting them, these are examples of planar graphs. We write

ùí¢ tree‚äÇùí¢ \mathcal{G}_{tree} \subset \mathcal{G}

for the subset of isomorphism classes of finite multigraphs with linearly orrdered vertices (def. 18) on those which are trees.

Proposition

(loop order and tree level of Feynman perturbation series)

The effective action (def. 22) contains no negative powers of ‚Ñè\hbar, hence is indeed a formal power series also in ‚Ñè\hbar:

S eff(g,j)‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]. S_{eff}(g,j) \;\in\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar, g, j ] ] \,.

and in particular

‚ü®S eff(g,j)‚ü©‚àà‚ÑÇ[[‚Ñè,g,j]]. \left\langle S_{eff}(g,j) \right\rangle \;\in\; \mathbb{C}[ [ \hbar, g, j] ] \,.

Moreover, the contribution to the effective action in the classical limit ‚Ñè‚Üí0\hbar \to 0 is precisely that of Feynman amplitudes of those finite multigraphs (prop. 13) which are trees (def. 23); thus called the tree level-contribution:

S eff(g,j)| ‚Ñè=0=i‚Ñè‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢ conn‚à©ùí¢ treeŒì((gS int+jA) i=1 ŒΩ(Œì)). S_{eff}(g,j)\vert_{\hbar = 0} \;=\; i \hbar \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}_{conn} \cap \mathcal{G}_{tree}}{\sum} \Gamma\left( (g S_{int} + j A)_{i = 1}^{\nu(\Gamma)} \right) \,.

Finally, a finite multigraph Œì\Gamma (def. 18) which is planar (def. 23) and connected (def. 21) contributes to the effective action precisely at order

‚Ñè L(Œì), \hbar^{L(\Gamma)} \,,

where L(Œì)‚àà‚ÑïL(\Gamma) \in \mathbb{N} is the number of faces of Œì\Gamma, here called the number of loops of the diagram; here usually called the loop order of Œì\Gamma.

(Beware the terminology clash with graph theory, see the discussion of tadpoles in remark 17.)

Proof

By def. 3 the explicit ‚Ñè\hbar-dependence of the S-matrix is

ùíÆ(S int)=‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï1k!1(i‚Ñè) kT(S int,‚ãØ,S int‚èükfactors) \mathcal{S} \left( S_{int} \right) \;=\; \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \frac{1}{k!} \frac{1}{(i \hbar)^k} T( \underset{k \, \text{factors}}{\underbrace{S_{int}, \cdots, S_{int}}} )

and by prop. 10 the further ‚Ñè\hbar-dependence of the time-ordered product T(‚ãØ)T(\cdots) is

T(S int,S int)=prod‚àòexp(‚Ñè‚ü®Œî F,Œ¥Œ¥Œ¶‚äóŒ¥Œ¥Œ¶‚ü©)(S int‚äóS int), T(S_{int}, S_{int}) \;=\; prod \circ \exp\left( \hbar \left\langle \Delta_F, \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}} \otimes \frac{\delta}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}} \right\rangle \right) ( S_{int} \otimes S_{int} ) \,,

By the Feynman rules (prop. 13) this means that

  1. each vertex of a Feynman diagram contributes a power ‚Ñè ‚àí1\hbar^{-1} to its Feynman amplitude;

  2. each edge of a Feynman diagram contributes a power ‚Ñè +1\hbar^{+1} to its Feynman amplitude.

If we write

E(Œì),V(Œì)‚àà‚Ñï E(\Gamma), V(\Gamma) \;\in\; \mathbb{N}

for the total number of vertices and edges, respectively, in Œì\Gamma, this means that a Feynman amplitude corresponding to some Œì‚ààùí¢\Gamma \in \mathcal{G} contributes precisely at order

(23)‚Ñè E(Œì)‚àíV(Œì). \hbar^{E(\Gamma) - V(\Gamma)} \,.

So far this holds for arbitrary Œì\Gamma. If however Œì\Gamma is connected (def. 21) and planar (def. 23), then Euler's formula asserts that

(24)E(Œì)‚àíV(Œì)=L(Œì)‚àí1. E(\Gamma) - V(\Gamma) \;=\; L(\Gamma) - 1 \,.

Hence ‚Ñè L(Œì)‚àí1\hbar^{L(\Gamma)- 1} is the order of ‚Ñè\hbar at which Œì\Gamma contributes to the scattering matrix expressed as the Feynman perturbation series.

But the effective action, by definition (21), has the same contributions of Feynman amplitudes, but multiplied by another power of ‚Ñè 1\hbar^1, hence it contributes at order

‚Ñè E(Œì)‚àíV(Œì)+1=‚Ñè L(Œì). \hbar^{E(\Gamma) - V(\Gamma) + 1} = \hbar^{L(\Gamma)} \,.

This proves the second claim on loop order.

The first claim, due to the extra factor of ‚Ñè\hbar in the definition of the effective action, is equivalent to saying that the Feynman amplitude of every connected finite multigraph contributes powers in ‚Ñè\hbar of order ‚â•‚àí1\geq -1 and contributes at order ‚Ñè ‚àí1\hbar^{-1} precisely if the graph is a tree.

Observe that a connected finite multigraph Œì\Gamma with ŒΩ‚àà‚Ñï\nu \in \mathbb{N} vertices (necessarily ŒΩ‚â•1\nu \geq 1) has at least ŒΩ‚àí1\nu-1 edges and precisely ŒΩ‚àí1\nu - 1 edges if it is a tree.

To see this, consecutively remove edges from Œì\Gamma as long as possible while retaining connectivity. When this process stops, the result must be a connected tree Œì‚Ä≤\Gamma', hence a connected planar graph with L(Œì‚Ä≤)=0L(\Gamma') = 0. Therefore Euler's formula (24) implies that that E(Œì‚Ä≤)=V(Œì‚Ä≤)‚àí1E(\Gamma') = V(\Gamma') -1.

This means that the connected multigraph Œì\Gamma in general has a Feynman amplitude of order

‚Ñè E(Œì)‚àíV(Œì)=‚Ñè E(Œì)‚àíE(Œì‚Ä≤)‚èû‚â•0+E(Œì‚Ä≤)‚àíV(Œì)‚èû=‚àí1 \hbar^{E(\Gamma) - V(\Gamma)} = \hbar^{ \overset{\geq 0}{\overbrace{E(\Gamma) - E(\Gamma')}} + \overset{= -1}{\overbrace{E(\Gamma') - V(\Gamma)}} }

and precisely if it is a tree its Feynman amplitude is of order ‚Ñè ‚àí1\hbar^{-1}.

\,

Vacuum diagrams

With the Feynman perturbation series and the effective action in hand, it is now immediate to see that there is a general contribution by vacuum diagrams (def. 24 below) in the scattering matrix which, in a stable vacuum state, cancels out against the prefactor ùíÆ(gS int)\mathcal{S}(g S_{int}) in Bogoliubov's formula for interacting field observables.

Definition

(vacuum diagrams)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, and let gS int+jA‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚ü®g,j‚ü©g S_{int} + j A \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar , g , j] ]\langle g,j \rangle be a local observable regarded as an adiabatically switched interaction action functional, and consider a choice of decomposition for field species and interaction vertices according to def. 19.

Then a Feynman diagram all whose vertices are internal vertices (def. 20) is called a vacuum diagram.

Write

ùí¢ vac Feyn‚äÇùí¢ Feyn \mathcal{G}^{Feyn}_{vac} \subset \mathcal{G}^{Feyn}

for the subset of isomorphism classes of vacuum diagrams among the set of isomorphism classes of all Feynman diagrams, def. 20. Similarly write

ùí¢ conn,vac Feyn‚âîùí¢ conn Feyn‚à©ùí¢ vac Feyn‚äÇùí¢ Feyn \mathcal{G}^{Feyn}_{conn,vac} \;\coloneqq\; \mathcal{G}^{Feyn}_{conn} \cap \mathcal{G}^{Feyn}_{vac} \;\subset\; \mathcal{G}^{Feyn}

for the subset of isomorphism classes of Feynman diagrams which are both vacuum diagrams as well as connected graphs (def. 21).

Finally write

S eff,vac(g)‚âî‚àë(Œì,vertlab,edgelab)‚ààùí¢ conn,vac(Œì,vertlab,edgelab)(gS int)‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST) mc[[‚Ñè,g]] S_{eff,vac}(g) \;\coloneqq\; \underset{ { (\Gamma,vertlab,edgelab) } \atop { \in \mathcal{G}_{conn,vac} } }{\sum} (\Gamma,vertlab, edgelab)(g S_{int}) \;\in\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{mc}[ [ \hbar , g ] ]

for the sub-series of that for the effective action (def. 22) given only by those connected diagrams which are also vacuum diagrams.

Example

(2-vertex vacuum diagram in QED)

The vacuum diagram (def. 24) with two electron-photon interaction-vertices in quantum electrodynamics (example \ref{LagrangianQED}) is:

Example

(vacuum diagram-contribution to S-matrices)

Let (E BV-BRST,L‚Ä≤,Œî H)(E_{\text{BV-BRST}}, \mathbf{L}', \Delta_H ) be a relativistic free vacuum according to def. 1, and let gS int+jA‚ààLocObs(E BV-BRST)[[‚Ñè,g,j]]‚ü®g,j‚ü©g S_{int} + j A \;\in\; LocObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})[ [ \hbar , g , j] ]\langle g,j \rangle be a local observable regarded as an adiabatically switched interaction action functional, and consider a choice of decomposition for field species and interaction vertices according to def. 19.

Then the Feynman perturbation series-expansion of the S-matrix (example 6) of the interaction-term gS intg S_{int} alone (no source field-contribution) is the series of Feynman amplitudes that are labeled by vacuum diagrams (def. 24), hence (by prop. 15) the exponential of the vacuum effective action S eff,vacS_{eff,vac} (def. 24):

ùíÆ(gS int) =exp ‚ãÖ(1i‚ÑèS eff,vac(g,j)) =‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢ vacŒì(gS int). \begin{aligned} \mathcal{S}(g S_{int}) & = \exp_\cdot\left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{eff,vac}(g,j) \right) \\ & = \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G}_{vac}}{\sum} \Gamma\left(g S_{int}\right) \end{aligned} \,.

More generally, the S-matrix with source field-contribution jAj A included always splits as a pointwise product of the vacuum S_matrix with the Feynman perturbation series over all Feynman graphs with at least one external vertex:

ùíÆ(gS int+jA)=ùíÆ(gS int)‚ãÖexp ‚ãÖ(1i‚Ñè(S eff(g,j)‚àíS eff,vac(g)))‚èüFeynman perturbation seriesover diagrams with at least one external vertex, \begin{aligned} \mathcal{S}(g S_{int} + j A) \;=\; \mathcal{S}(g S_{int}) \cdot \underset{ \text{Feynman perturbation series} \atop \text{over diagrams with at least one external vertex} }{ \underbrace{ \exp_\cdot \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} \left( S_{eff}(g,j) - S_{eff,vac}(g) \right) \right) } } \,, \end{aligned}

Hence if the free field vacuum state is stable with respect to the interaction gS intg S_{int}, according to def. 6, then the vacuum expectation value of a time-ordered product of interacting field observables j(A i) intj (A_i)_{int} (example 2) and hence in particular of scattering amplitudes (example 3) is given by the Feynman perturbation series (example 6) over just the non-vacuum Feynman diagrams, hence over all those diagram that have at least one one external vertex

(supp(A 1)‚à®‚àßsupp(A 2)‚à®‚àß‚ãØ‚à®‚àßsupp(A n)) ‚áí‚ü®(A 1) int(A 2) int‚ãØ(A n) int‚ü©=d ndj 1‚ãØdj n(‚àëŒì‚ààùí¢‚àñùí¢ vacŒì(gS int+‚àë ij iA i)) |j 1,‚ãØ,j n=0. \begin{aligned} & \left( {\, \atop \,} supp(A_1) {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} supp(A_2) {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} \cdots {\vee\!\!\!\wedge} supp(A_n) {\, \atop \,} \right) \\ & \Rightarrow \left\langle {\, \atop \,} (A_1)_int (A_2)_{int} \cdots (A_n)_{int} {\, \atop \,} \right\rangle \;=\; \frac{d^n}{ d j_1 \cdots d j_n} \left( \underset{\Gamma \in \mathcal{G} \setminus \mathcal{G}_{vac} }{\sum} \Gamma(g S_{int} + \sum_i j_i A_i) \right)_{ \vert j_1, \cdots, j_n = 0 } \,. \end{aligned}

This is the way in which the Feynman perturbation series is used in practice for computing scattering amplitudes.

\,

BV-Differential and Ward identities

Finally we discuss how the BV-differential passes from the Wick algebra of observables of the free field theory to the interacting field algebra of observables of the interacting perturbative QFT.

\,

Recall how the global BV-differential

{S‚Ä≤,‚àí}:PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg[[‚Ñè]]‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg[[‚Ñè]] \{S',-\} \;\colon\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}[ [\hbar] ] \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}[ [\hbar] ]

on regular polynomial observables (def. \ref{BVDifferentialGlobal}) is conjugated into the time-ordered product via the time ordering operator ùíØ‚àò{‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚àí}‚àòùíØ ‚àí\mathcal{T} \circ \{-S',-\} \circ \mathcal{T}^{-} (prop. \ref{GaugeFixedActionFunctionalTimeOrderedAntibracket}).

In the same way we may use the quantum M√∏ller operators to conjugate the BV-differential into the regular part of the interacting field algebra of observables:

Definition

(interacting quantum BV-differential)

Given an adiabatically switched non-point-interaction action functional in the form of a regular polynomial observable S intS_{int}, then the interacting quantum BV-differential on the interacting field algebra (def. 15) on regular polynomial observables is the conjugation of the plain BV-differential {‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚àí}\{-S',-\} by the quantum M√∏ller operator induced by S intS_{int} (def. 14):

‚Ñõ‚àò{‚àíS‚Ä≤,(‚àí)}‚àò‚Ñõ ‚àí1:PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg[[‚Ñè]]‚ü∂PolyObs(E BV-BRST) reg[[‚Ñè]]. \mathcal{R} \circ \{-S', (-)\} \circ \mathcal{R}^{-1} \;\colon\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}[ [\hbar] ] \longrightarrow PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{reg}[ [\hbar] ] \,.

(Rejzner 11, (5.38))

Proposition

(quantum master equation and quantum master Ward identity on regular polynomial observables)

Consider an adiabatically switched non-point-interaction action functional in the form of a regular polynomial observable in degree 0

S int‚ààPolyObs(E BV-BRST) regdeg=0[[‚Ñè]], S_{int} \;\in\; PolyObs(E_{\text{BV-BRST}})_{{reg} \atop {deg = 0}}[ [\hbar] ] \,,

Then the following are equivalent:

  1. The quantum master equation (QME)

    (25)12{S‚Ä≤+S int,S‚Ä≤+S int} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV(S‚Ä≤+S int)=0. \tfrac{1}{2} \{ S' + S_{int}, S' + S_{int} \}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV}( S' + S_{int} ) \;=\; 0 \,.

  2. The perturbative S-matrix (def. 13) is BVBV-closed

    {‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)}=0. \{-S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int})\} = 0 \,.

  3. The quantum master Ward identity (MWI) on regular polynomial observables in terms of retarded products:

    (26)‚Ñõ‚àò{‚àíS‚Ä≤,(‚àí)}‚àò‚Ñõ ‚àí1=‚àí({S‚Ä≤+S int,(‚àí)} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV) \mathcal{R} \circ \{-S',(-)\} \circ \mathcal{R}^{-1} \;=\; - \left( \left\{ S' + S_{int} \,,\, (-) \right\}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV} \right)

    (D√ºtsch 18, (4.2))

    expressing the interacting quantum BV-differential (def. 25) as the sum of the time-ordered antibracket (def. \ref{AntibracketTimeOrdered}) with the total action functional S‚Ä≤+S intS' + S_{int} and i‚Ñèi \hbar times the BV-operator (BV-operator).

  4. The quantum master Ward identity (MWI) on regular polynomial observables in terms of time-ordered products:

    (27)ùíÆ(‚àíS int)‚ãÜ F{‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ F(‚àí)}=‚àí({S‚Ä≤+S int,(‚àí)} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV) \mathcal{S}(-S_{int}) \star_F \{-S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F (-)\} \;=\; - \left( \left\{ S' + S_{int} \,,\, (-) \right\}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV} \right)

    (D√ºtsch 18, (4.8))

(Rejzner 11, (5.35) - (5.38), following Hollands 07, (342)-(345))

Proof

To see that the first two conditions are equivalent, we compute as follows

(28){‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)} ={‚àíS‚Ä≤,exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)} ={‚àíS‚Ä≤,exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)} ùíØ‚èü‚àí1i‚Ñè{S‚Ä≤,S} ùíØ‚ãÜ Fexp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)‚àíi‚ÑèŒî BV(exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int))‚èü(1i‚ÑèŒî BV(S int)+12(i‚Ñè) 2{S int,S int} ùíØ)‚ãÜ Fexp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int) =‚àí1i‚Ñè({S‚Ä≤,S int}+12{S int,S int}+i‚ÑèŒî BV(S int))‚èüQME‚ãÜ Fexp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int) \begin{aligned} \left\{ -S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \right\} & = \left\{ -S' , \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \right\} \\ & = \underset{ { \tfrac{-1}{i \hbar} \{S',S\}_{\mathcal{T}} } \atop { \star_F \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) } }{ \underbrace{ \left\{ -S' , \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \right\}_{\mathcal{T}} } } - i \hbar \underset{ { \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} \Delta_{BV}(S_{int}) + \tfrac{1}{2 (i \hbar)^2} \left\{ S_{int}, S_{int} \right\}_{\mathcal{T}} \right) } \atop { \star_{F} \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) } }{ \underbrace{ \Delta_{BV} \left( \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \right) } } \\ & = \tfrac{-1}{i \hbar} \underset{ \text{QME} }{ \underbrace{ \left( \{S',S_{int}\} + \tfrac{1}{2}\{S_{int}, S_{int}\} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV}(S_{int}) \right) } } \star_F \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \end{aligned}

Here in the first step we used the definition of the BV-operator (def. \ref{ForGaugeFixedFreeLagrangianFieldTheoryBVOperator}) to rewrite the plain antibracket in terms of the time-ordered antibracket (def. \ref{AntibracketTimeOrdered}), then under the second brace we used that the time-ordered antibracket is the failure of the BV-operator to be a derivation (prop. \ref{AntibracketBVOperatorRelation}) and under the first brace the consequence of this statement for application to exponentials (example \ref{TimeOrderedExponentialBVOperator}). Finally we collected terms, and to ‚Äúcomplete the square‚Äù we added the terms on the left of

12{S‚Ä≤,S‚Ä≤} ùíØ‚èü=0‚àíi‚ÑèŒî BV(S‚Ä≤)‚èü=0=0 \frac{1}{2} \underset{= 0}{\underbrace{\{S', S'\}_{\mathcal{T}}}} - i \hbar \underset{ = 0}{\underbrace{ \Delta_{BV}(S')}} = 0

which vanish because, by definition of gauge fixing (def. \ref{GaugeFixingLagrangianDensity}), the free gauge-fixed action functional S‚Ä≤S' is independent of antifields.

But since the operation (‚àí)‚ãÜ Fexp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)(-) \star_F \exp_{\mathcal{T}}\left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) has the inverse (‚àí)‚ãÜ Fexp ùíØ(‚àí1i‚ÑèS int)(-) \star_F \exp_{\mathcal{T}}\left( \tfrac{-1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right), this implies the claim.

Next we show that the quantum master equation implies the quantum master Ward identities.

We use that the BV-differential {‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚àí}\{-S',-\} is a derivation of the Wick algebra product ‚ãÜ H\star_H (lemma \ref{DerivationBVDifferentialForWickAlgebra}).

First of all this implies that with {‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)}=0\{-S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int})\} = 0 also {‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1}=0\{-S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1}\} = 0.

Thus we compute as follows:

{‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚àí}‚àò‚Ñõ ‚àí1(A) ={‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚Ñõ ‚àí1(A)} ={‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1‚ãÜ H(ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ Fa)} =+{‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1}‚èü=0‚ãÜ H(ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ FA) =+ùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1‚ãÜ H{‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ FA} =ùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1‚ãÜ H(ùíÆ(+S int)‚ãÜ FùíÆ(‚àíS int)‚èü=1‚ãÜ F{‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ FA}) =ùíÆ(S int) ‚àí1‚ãÜ H(ùíÆ(+S int)‚ãÜ FùíÆ(‚àíS int)‚ãÜ F{‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ FA}‚èü(*)) =‚Ñõ ‚àí1(ùíÆ(‚àíS int)‚ãÜ F{‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ FA}‚èü(*)) \begin{aligned} \{-S', -\} \circ \mathcal{R}^{-1}(A) & = \{-S', \mathcal{R}^{-1}(A)\} \\ & = \left\{ { \, \atop \, } -S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1} \star_H \left( \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F a \right) {\, \atop \,} \right\} \\ & = \phantom{+} \underset{ = 0 }{ \underbrace{ \left\{ -S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1} \right\} } } \star_H \left( \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F A \right) \\ & \phantom{=} + \mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1} \star_H \left\{ -S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F A \right\} \\ & = \mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1} \star_H \left( \underset{ = 1 }{ \underbrace{ \mathcal{S}(+ S_{int}) \star_F \mathcal{S}(- S_{int}) } } \star_F \left\{ -S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F A \right\} \right) \\ & = \mathcal{S}(S_{int})^{-1} \star_H \left( \mathcal{S}(+ S_{int}) \star_F \underset{ (\ast) }{ \underbrace{ \mathcal{S}(- S_{int}) \star_F \left\{ -S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F A \right\} } } \right) \\ & = \mathcal{R}^{-1} \left( \underset{ (\ast) }{ \underbrace{ \phantom{\, \atop \,} \mathcal{S}(-S_{int}) \star_F \left\{ -S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F A \right\} } } \right) \end{aligned}

By applying ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R} to both sides of this equation, this means first of all that the interacting quantum BV-differential is equivalently given by

‚Ñõ‚àò{‚àíS‚Ä≤,(‚àí)}‚àò‚Ñõ ‚àí1=ùíÆ(‚àíS int)‚ãÜ F{‚àíS‚Ä≤,ùíÆ(S int)‚ãÜ F(‚àí)}, \mathcal{R} \circ \{-S', (-)\} \circ \mathcal{R}^{-1} \;=\; \mathcal{S}(-S_{int}) \star_F \{-S', \mathcal{S}(S_{int}) \star_F (-)\} \,,

hence that if either version (26) or (27) of the master Ward identity holds, it implies the other.

Now expanding out the definition of ùíÆ\mathcal{S} (def. 13) and expressing {‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚àí}\{-S',-\} via the time-ordered antibracket (def. \ref{AntibracketTimeOrdered}) and the BV-operator Œî BV\Delta_{BV} (prop. \ref{ForGaugeFixedFreeLagrangianFieldTheoryBVOperator}) as

{‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚àí}={‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚àí} ùíØ‚àíi‚ÑèŒî BV \{-S',-\} \;=\; \{-S',-\}_{\mathcal{T}} - i \hbar \Delta_{BV}

(on regular polynomial observables), we continue computing as follows:

(29) ‚Ñõ‚àò{‚àíS‚Ä≤,(‚àí)}‚àò‚Ñõ ‚àí1(A) =exp ùíØ(‚àí1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ F{‚àíS‚Ä≤,exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ FA} =exp ùíØ(‚àí1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ F({‚àíS‚Ä≤,exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ FA} ùíØ‚àíi‚ÑèŒî BV(exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ FA)) +=1i‚Ñè{‚àíS‚Ä≤,S int} ùíØ‚ãÜ FA+{‚àíS‚Ä≤,A} ùíØ =‚àíi‚Ñèexp ùíØ(‚àí1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ F(Œî BV(exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int))‚èü(1i‚ÑèŒî BV(S int)+12(i‚Ñè) 2{S int,S int})‚ãÜ Fexp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ FA+exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ FŒî BV(A)+{exp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int),A} ùíØ‚èüexp ùíØ(1i‚ÑèS int)‚ãÜ F1i‚Ñè{S int,A}) =‚àí({S‚Ä≤+S int,A} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV(A)) =‚àí1i‚Ñè(12{S‚Ä≤+S int,S‚Ä≤+S int} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV(S‚Ä≤+S int))‚èüQME‚ãÜ FA =‚àí({S‚Ä≤+S int,A} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV(A)) \begin{aligned} & \mathcal{R} \circ \{-S', (-)\} \circ \mathcal{R}^{-1}( A ) \\ & = \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{-1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \star_F \left\{ -S', \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \star_F A \right\} \\ & = \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{-1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \star_F \left( \left\{ -S', \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{ 1 }{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \star_F A \right\}_{\mathcal{T}} - i \hbar \Delta_{BV} \left( \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{ 1 }{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \star_F A \right) \right) \\ & \phantom{+} = \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} \{ -S', S_{int} \}_{\mathcal{T}} \star_F A + \{-S', A\}_{\mathcal{T}} \\ & \phantom{=} - i \hbar \exp_{\mathcal{T}}\left( \tfrac{-1}{i \hbar} S_{int}\right) \star_F \left( \underset{ { \left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar}\Delta_{BV}(S_{int}) + \tfrac{1}{2 (i \hbar)^2} \left\{ S_{int}, S_{int} \right\} \right) } \atop { \star_F \exp_{\mathcal{T}}\left( \tfrac{ 1 }{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) } }{ \underbrace{ \Delta_{BV} \left( \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{ 1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \right) } } \star_F A \,+\, \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{ 1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \star_F \Delta_{BV}(A) \,+\, \underset{ { \exp_{\mathcal{T}}\left( \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) } \atop { \star_F \tfrac{ 1}{i \hbar} \{S_{int}, A\} } }{ \underbrace{ \left\{ \exp_{\mathcal{T}} \left( \tfrac{ 1}{i \hbar} S_{int} \right) \,,\, A \right\}_{\mathcal{T}} } } \right) \\ & = - \left( \{ S' + S_{int}\,,\, A\}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV}(A) \right) \\ & \phantom{=} - \tfrac{1}{i \hbar} \underset{ \text{QME} }{ \underbrace{ \left( \tfrac{1}{2} \{ S' + S_{int}, S' + S_{int} \}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV}( S' + S_{int} ) \right) }} \star_F A \\ & = - \left( \{ S' + S_{int}\,,\, A\}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV}(A) \right) \end{aligned}

Here in the line with the braces we used that the BV-operator is a derivation of the time-ordered product up to correction by the time-ordered antibracket (prop. \ref{AntibracketBVOperatorRelation}), and under the first brace we used the effect of that property on time-ordered exponentials (example \ref{TimeOrderedExponentialBVOperator}), while under the second brace we used that {(‚àí),A} ùíØ\{(-),A\}_{\mathcal{T}} is a derivation of the time-ordered product. Finally we have collected terms, added 0={S‚Ä≤,S‚Ä≤}+i‚ÑèŒî BV(S‚Ä≤)0 = \{S',S'\} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV}(S') as before, and then used the QME.

This shows that the quantum master Ward identities follow from the quantum master equation. To conclude, it is now sufficient to show that, conversely, the MWI in terms of, say, retarded products implies the QME.

To see this, observe that with the BV-differential being nilpotent, also its conjugation by ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R} is, so that with the above we have:

({‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚àí}) 2=0 ‚áî (‚Ñõ‚àò{‚àíS‚Ä≤,(‚àí)}‚àò‚Ñõ ‚àí1) 2=0 ‚áî ({S‚Ä≤+S int,(‚àí)} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV) 2‚èü{12{S‚Ä≤+S int,S‚Ä≤+S int} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV(S‚Ä≤+S int),(‚àí)}=0 \begin{aligned} & \left( \{-S',-\}\right)^2 = 0 \\ \Leftrightarrow \; & \left( \mathcal{R} \circ \{-S',(-)\} \circ \mathcal{R}^{-1} \right)^2 = 0 \\ \Leftrightarrow \; & \underset{ \left\{ {\, \atop \,} \tfrac{1}{2}\{S' + S_{int}, S' + S_{int}\}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV}(S' + S_{int}) \,,\, (-) \right\} }{ \underbrace{ \left( \{S' + S_{int}, (-)\}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV} \right)^2 } } = 0 \end{aligned}

Here under the brace we computed as follows:

({S‚Ä≤+S int,(‚àí)} ùíØ+i‚ÑèŒî BV) 2 =+{S‚Ä≤+S int,{S‚Ä≤+S int} ùíØ,(‚àí)} ùíØ‚èü12{{S‚Ä≤+S,S‚Ä≤+S} ùíØ,(‚àí)} ùíØ =+i‚Ñè({S‚Ä≤+S int,(‚àí)} ùíØ‚àòŒî BV+Œî BV‚àò{S‚Ä≤+S int,(‚àí)} ùíØ)‚èü{Œî BV(S‚Ä≤+S),(‚àí)} ùíØ =+(i‚Ñè) 2Œî BV‚àòŒî BV‚èü=0. \begin{aligned} \left( \{S' + S_{int}, (-)\}_{\mathcal{T}} + i \hbar \Delta_{BV} \right)^2 & = \phantom{+} \underset{ \tfrac{1}{2} \{ \{S' + S, S'+ S\}_{\mathcal{T}}, (-) \}_{\mathcal{T}} }{ \underbrace{ \{S' + S_{int}, \{S' + S_{int}\}_{\mathcal{T}}, (-) \}_{\mathcal{T}} }} \\ & \phantom{=} + i \hbar \underset{ \{ \Delta_{BV}(S'+ S)\,,\, (-) \}_{\mathcal{T}} }{ \underbrace{ \left( \{S' + S_{int}, (-)\}_{\mathcal{T}} \circ \Delta_{BV} + \Delta_{BV} \circ \{S' + S_{int}, (-)\}_{\mathcal{T}} \right) }} \\ & \phantom{=} + (i \hbar)^2 \underset{= 0} { \underbrace{ \Delta_{BV} \circ \Delta_{BV} } } \end{aligned} \,.

where, in turn, the term under the first brace follows by the graded Jacobi identity, the one under the second brace by Henneaux-Teitelboim (15.105c) and the one under the third brace by Henneaux-Teitelboim (15.105b).

Example

(classical master Ward identity)

The classical limit ‚Ñè‚Üí0\hbar \to 0 of the quantum master Ward identity (26) is

{‚àíS‚Ä≤,(‚àí)}‚àò‚Ñõ ‚àí1=‚àí‚Ñõ ‚àí1({S‚Ä≤+S int,(‚àí)}). \{-S',(-)\} \circ \mathcal{R}^{-1} \;=\; - \mathcal{R}^{-1} \left( \left\{ S' + S_{int} \,,\, (-) \right\} \right) \,.

Applied to an observable which is linear in the antifields

A=‚à´Œ£A a(x)Œ¶ a ‚Ä°(x)dvol Œ£(x) A \;=\; \underset{\Sigma}{\int} A^a(x) \mathbf{\Phi}^\ddagger_a(x) \, dvol_\Sigma(x)

this becomes

0 ={‚àíS‚Ä≤,‚Ñõ ‚àí1(A)}+‚Ñõ ‚àí1({S‚Ä≤+S int,A} ùíØ) =‚à´Œ£Œ¥S‚Ä≤Œ¥Œ¶ a(x)‚Ñõ ‚àí1(A a(x))dvol Œ£(x)+‚Ñõ ‚àí1(‚à´Œ£A a(x)Œ¥(S‚Ä≤+S int)Œ¥Œ¶ a(x)dvol Œ£(x)) \begin{aligned} 0 & = \{-S', \mathcal{R}^{-1}(A)\} + \mathcal{R}^{-1} \left( \left\{ S' + S_{int} \,,\, A \right\}_{\mathcal{T}} \right) \\ & = \underset{\Sigma}{\int} \frac{\delta S'}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}^a(x)} \mathcal{R}^{-1}(A^a(x)) \, dvol_\Sigma(x) + \mathcal{R}^{-1} \left( \underset{\Sigma}{\int} A^a(x) \frac{\delta (S' + S_{int})}{\delta \mathbf{\Phi}^a(x)} \, dvol_\Sigma(x) \right) \end{aligned}

In this form the classical Master Ward identity was originally identified in (D√ºtsch-Fredenhagen 02, (90), Brennecke-D√ºtsch 07, (5.5), following D√ºtsch-Boas 02).
